name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: author. – Madam President, our efforts in climate change mitigation are noble. Our progress in defining new, bold and ambitious targets and goals in this parliamentary term is inspiring. We can be proud of having approved the first climate law in the world and of what we are doing to achieve climate neutrality in 30 years. We are doing what we were elected to do: to shape a better, brighter and cleaner future for us all, in particular for future generations. I am proud to be taking part in this challenge and, hopefully, in this accomplishment.  But the planet is now waiting for us to do our part. We are already facing extreme weather events, devastating fires, severe droughts, floods and devastating storms. We need, quickly and effectively, to adapt our territory, our cities, our economies and our infrastructure. We need to invest in sustainable and nature-based solutions, protect the economy from climate problems, and improve the resilience of critical infrastructure, adding climate factors to risk management practices, stepping up prevention and preparedness efforts, and making use of technological advancements.  But many are already suffering: Spaniards, Portuguese, Italians, Greeks, Cypriots, Bulgarians and Romanians. Our fellow Europeans living in these countries are already facing severe risks of desertification across over half of their territory. For example, in Spain, 75% of the country is at risk of desertification, and one-fifth of the territory is at a high risk of irreversibly becoming desert. If we are, rightly, financing climate mitigation and transition mechanisms for countries lagging in their energy transition from coal to renewable energy sources, why are we forgetting the countries that are already suffering from climate change, the ones among us who are already burdened by a non-recoverable debt that is maturing in their biodiversity? How does this make sense? We need to advance with adaptation funding, a sort of fair climate adaptation mechanism, to help these cities and regions.  I’m sure I don’t need to explain how it is that everyone will lose if we don’t act now to adapt and reduce these climate change effects. Our food supply chains, our industries and our economies will be disrupted. We must fix the climate and the environment if we are to live better and have better jobs.  Rest assured, you will not find the EPP arguing in the trenches for the economy and being hostile towards the environment, nor fighting for the climate by shouting for the destruction of the economy or an end to the social market economy. We need both. We need the economy and the environment, and we need them to work together.  Senhor Presidente, caras e caros Colegas, as temperaturas médias globais europeias repetidamente quebraram recordes nos últimos anos. Em particular os 5 últimos anos foram os mais quentes já registados com ondas de calor, secas e incêndios florestais em toda a Europa, com centenas de mortos. E estes impactos são transfronteiriços, afetam a nossa saúde, destroem a nossa agricultura, limitam o comércio e obrigam a migrações e reduzem a nossa segurança. Precisamos, por isso, que a nova estratégia para a adaptação às alterações climáticas contenha respostas concretas relativas à desertificação e à degradação dos solos. Precisamos de novas construções e infraestruturas que sejam resistentes e eficientes. Precisamos de aproveitar melhor o potencial das florestas, que não só retiram o carbono da atmosfera como amenizam a temperatura e retêm a humidade. Precisamos de melhorar os sistemas de alerta rápido contra desastres, tirando partido do potencial das novas tecnologias e dos dados. Precisamos de investir na gestão eficiente da água, que se torna escassa.  Da nossa capacidade e dos nossos esforços de adaptação de hoje depende um futuro mais saudável e mais pacífico na Europa.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is good to see you again. Honourable Members, the last five years were the hottest on record, with more frequent heatwaves, droughts and wildfires across Europe. Temporary drops in greenhouse gas emissions like those caused by the 2008 financial crisis and the current economic disruptions due to the COVID—19 pandemic have little effect on the evolution of the planetary climate, and emissions can bounce back quickly.  The Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5° Celsius issued by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change demonstrates that even in a best case scenario of sustained emission limitations, there will be large stress on agri—food systems, infrastructure, ecosystems and human health.  The Union was an early actor on adaptation, with the adoption in 2013 of a Strategy on Adaptation to Climate Change. This aimed to enhance the preparedness and capacity of all governance levels to respond to the impacts of climate change and make Europe more climate resilient. The new strategy will draw on its evaluation that was finalised in 2018 and, of course, will also take account of the European Green Deal ambitions.  Efforts to measure resilience to climate change need to continue and to be upgraded and linked to a more ambitious monitoring and evaluation system.  The 2013 strategy relied on the scoreboard to assess preparedness. The revised strategy could use a dashboard to assess resilience and subsequently monitor its strength over time, with regular progress reports on specific targets. At the same time, strengthening effective monitoring and evaluation tools for adaptation policies and measures in partner countries will continue to be of central interest for the Union’s international action and support. The Commission’s proposal for a European climate law provides a framework for progress in pursuit of the global adaptation goal established in Article 7 of the Paris Agreement. The adaptation strategy will be designed to support the achievement of the objectives of the proposal. The governance will include a citizens’ dimension through the recently—launched climate pact. The revised strategy will be accompanied by an impact assessment and will draw on the latest available research results. Adaptation action in general, and the strategy in particular, will benefit from the increased climate—related spending target in the next Union seven—year budget, while the European Investment Bank has committed in its recently—adopted climate roadmap to support its implementation. Stakeholders will be empowered to tackle climate impacts like desertification and land degradation.  Climate change adaptation and disaster risk management will be a key priority for the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund in the 2021—2027 period, with a place—based approach to improving the resilience of EU regions and cities.  Today, the speed of adaptation actions varies across the Union, with all Member States having adopted national adaptation strategies or plans. In the EU Member States, most vulnerability assessments are being made, and adaptations identified, in respect of agriculture, health, biodiversity, forestry, energy, oceans and seas. The European Environment Agency concludes that even if the Union and some countries have started to monitor the implementation of adaptation activities, it’s not possible to determine with any certainty whether decisive progress in increased resilience at Union level has been achieved by 2020.  While building resilience and adapting to the impacts of climate change is a challenge for all regions of the world, it’s the poorest and most vulnerable who are least able to adapt, both with the Union and globally, for example because of limited resources, protracted crises or violence.  Globally, the Union and its Member States remain the largest contributor of international public climate finance for adaptation purposes to developing countries, in particular least—developed countries and small island developing states. The Union and its Member States are committed to scaling up their financial assistance in the future.  Water resources, forests and agricultural crops fulfil many critical productive and regulation functions upon which our societies depend, such as clean drinking water, carbon sequestration, abundant food, wood and forest products, outdoor recreation opportunities and habitat. Ensuring water, forests and agriculture can withstand a changing climate is critical to reaching essential goals, including preserving ecosystem services and not least the carbon sequestration potential of forests. The Commission will take this issue up in all fora, including for cities in the global Covenant of Mayors. This issue is essential and the Commission welcomes Parliament’s early engagement and clear signal for ambition.  We look forward to the upcoming parliamentary resolution on the new strategy and to engaging in fruitful discussion on implementation once the Commission adopts the new strategy. But may I say that we also have to take care that the issue of implementation is properly addressed in the different sectoral legislation. The reports I have received so far are not very promising, at this stage at least.

name: Marek Paweł BALT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. The motion for a resolution on a climate change adaptation strategy for the European Union is a very important document for the future of the people of the european Union as a whole. I am pleased that this huge green deal, led by Mr Timmermans, has started, so in addition to these measures to minimise climate change, I have decided to adapt to the effects of climate change that we are experiencing every day. This is a really serious problem that all mankind has to face. The decisions we are making now will be crucial to preventing the effects of climate change.  The resolution raises a number of important issues. I ask the Commission to take note of them. The most important proposals m.in. the development of urban strategies, which will include harnessing the potential of all urban infrastructure, m.in. such as urban gardens or green roofs and pavements.  I know that we are all aware of how much climate change will affect our lives and our environment. I would particularly like to draw attention to cities, because today more than two thirds of Europe's population lives in urban areas, or more than 350 million people, and this percentage is constantly increasing. Rising air temperatures of more than 1.5 degrees Celsius can raise the ground temperature to more than 60 degrees. That is why it is so important to green these areas, whether in terms of roofs, roads or even glazed buildings.  It is probably at this point in Europe that investment work is underway, which is co-financed by EU funds. I therefore ask for an answer as to whether these investments took into account the effects of climate change during the design phase. If not, I call on my colleagues to pay particular attention to this, because urban infrastructure can make a significant contribution to reducing the Union's overall vulnerability to climate change.  In order to make positive changes, we need to take into account many ecologically important aspects. The investment plans of all Member States and of all areas that include climate change, including research and development, must take into account our strategy. We should not forget to develop appropriate rapid response plans for climate disasters such as heat waves, floods and droughts.  I would like to address many of the misdemeasied allegations that I have the opportunity to observe on social media. They suggest that since there is heavy rainfall, which results in flooding or flooding, it is ible to talk about drought or global warming. Dear! It is enough to ask farmers whether violent downpours irrigate crops, and we will get the answer that violent and heavy rains do not provide plants with enough water, because this one simply drains from the ground, very often destroying crops. I would therefore also like to pay particular attention to agriculture, which also faces many challenges in adapting to climate change.  I would also like to call on all European local authorities to follow european cities that have adopted local law pursuing the European Union's climate objectives. Achieving climate neutrality in terms of greenhouse gas emissions requires the active participation of both government and local authorities, as well as all sectors of the economy and society as a whole. Thus, local authorities can be an active partner for the industrial and construction sector and, through the implementation of projects at local level, actively support the implementation of the EU climate strategy.  Mother Earth responds to human activity, which is why we all – regardless of the profession we represent – must realize the seriousness of the problem and work together to prevent climate change.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Renew-ryhmän puolesta. – Arvoisa puhemies, terveisiä Helsingistä. Tässä vaiheessa siirryn puhumaan englanniksi. The effects of climate change will spread across our continent. Adaptation is required to make measures at all levels transformative enough to deal with the systemic changes our climate, environment and society are facing. Throughout history, people and societies have adapted to climate variability and extremes with varying degrees of success. Taking responsibility for climate—related risk requires decision—making in a changing world with continued uncertainty on climate impact and with limitation on how effective the adaptation will be.  Climate change impacts are more and more visible, with heatwaves, droughts, and wildfires across Europe and no snow for Christmas in Helsinki. Climate change will continue to create significant difficulties in Europe in spite of mitigation efforts. Moreover, Europe is affected by indirect climate impacts occurring in other parts of the world in multiple ways, such as through trade and supply chains, spread of infections and threats to international security. It is therefore crucial that Parliament is in the forefront of pushing for stronger EU policies and adaptation. I would like to end with a note that the main work, for our part, was done by Fredrick Federley and his assistant Stina Jansson. I’m just sort of taking the leading points for the very last few minutes and seconds.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The climate crisis is here and now. Unfortunately, we have already waited too long for the radical shift needed to combat climate change and reduce our emissions. Unfortunately, therefore, the crisis will get worse, and unfortunately the proposals now under discussion in the climate law, for example, are not enough to reduce emissions, quickly enough. The World Meteorological Organization showed in its latest report that there is a 20 percent chance that we will reach 1.5 degrees as early as 2024, that is, within four years. People are already dying, people are already fleeing, and people are already losing their livelihoods, not only elsewhere, far away, but indeed also here in Europe. I am thinking in particular of sweden's indigenous people, the Sami, and their reindeer herds. I am thinking of Spanish winegrowers and Italian farmers. I am also thinking of the mass biological death, which means that one million species are threatened with extinction globally.  We simply need a much, much more resilient Europe. The key is a Europe in which sustainable development and biodiversity are always a priority, and where quality of life, public health, access to food and clean water are ensured for all citizens. We need holistic solutions that both limit climate change and adapt to the challenges ahead.  Sure, it's going to cost money. At the same time, we know that if we do not do enough, it will be much, much more expensive. Solidarity is becoming more important than ever. We must also adapt our social systems to climate change. Society's most vulnerable will be hardest hit. We need a gender perspective. We need a Europe of solidarity. We know what's in store for us. Not to prepare and adapt to protect our societies and prevent the worst disasters would not only be irresponsible, but would be downright criminal.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. For climate action, human, nature to be effective, at least three conditions must be met. Firstly, education and civic awareness, secondly, coherent law, thirdly, money. And let me focus on a consistent law. The strategy is important and we thank you for being debated. However, we can see what is happening with climate law, with Article 4 saying that the strategy should be adopted by 31 January. Yes, until 31 January, but climate law is only at the preliminary stage of discussions in trilogues. All indications are that this will take many months.  At the same time, climate law and the climate change adaptation strategy also mean changes in at least three regulations: the ESR, LULUCF or the ECJ. And we don't see any work going on there. And I would remind you that climate law makes it clear that by the end of June 2021, every provision must be examined and adapted to climate law.  This is very important, because if we adopt laws that are different and do not see each other, there will be legal chaos, and that really won't help. At the same time, there is simply no money in the general budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework, as well as in the budget for rebuilding Europe for a strategy for adapting to climate change and biodiversity.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, we look forward to the Commission's new proposals to revise the adaptation strategy in the midst of the climate crisis, which jeopardises the continuity of human civilization.  It is now deadly clear that our bad practices have violated the planetary boundary. Today we are already in another world, 1.2 degrees Celsius warmer, a world that at best successful global cooperation will be at least 1.5 degrees warmer. When we consider that this was precisely the temperature difference between the ice age and ours, the one that allowed human civilization to flourish, we understand how gigantic the task of adaptation is.  We have no choice but to take bold adaptation measures now to deal with the inevitable climate impacts on their social, economic and environmental costs. The new adaptation strategy should be very ambitious. Social cohesion, the clear distinction between adaptation and adaptation investments, the gender dimension, climate refugees, the creation of a mechanism for loss and damage, the strengthening of the resilience of island regions are thematic areas that should guide the new strategy.  Enhanced governance of adaptation, both at European Union and Member State and local government level, as outlined in Parliament's proposal in climate legislation, should include legally binding targets. For us, adaptation doesn't mean we rely on natural selection to survive the strongest. On the contrary, it is an opportunity to take effective and immediate action to build a more resilient and just society. We expect the Commission to respond to our call and to look even more ambitious than there has been in the European Green Agreement.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Members for this short but intensive discussion. Certainly, we will continue to do our utmost to prevent the unadaptable, such as a global warming level of 3⁰ Celsius that will make life impossible in many places. We must also adapt to the unpreventable as we are now already at 1.2⁰ Celsius and the climate impacts are hitting us hard.  The Commission welcomes very much Parliament’s early engagement on adaptation and the clear signals and encouragement it has given for increased ambition and adaptation.  I fully agree with Mr Balt on the issue that cities play a crucial role in this, and I know that many, many cities have very elaborate and ambitious plans, ideas and concrete projects, but it’s also up to the national authorities to provide the necessary financial means. Here I can only plead to all of you to use the opportunities provided by the MFF and the different programmes.  But it’s also on us to be engaged enough on this issue when it comes to agreeing on the different sectoral regulations, because it’s a horizontal issue and it’s not sufficient to be very committed within the climate and environmental caucus; it’s also important to be strict and ambitious across the board, if I may say so.  Here I can only once again urge you to reach out to your colleagues in the different groups, when they are negotiating their sectoral programmes, to indeed address this issue and not to wait until certain modifications in the legislation is necessary, as already mentioned by Ms Zalewska. We’re looking forward to the upcoming resolution on the new Adaptation Strategy and also expect again not only a fruitful discussion on, but a very engaged and ambitious implementation of, this strategy across the different sectoral topics.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – We will discuss the EU strategy for adaptation to climate change in the European Parliament tomorrow.  We will vote on a resolution re-emphasising the impact of climate change on ecosystems, particularly biodiversity; the social and economic sectors, and the associated deepening of inequalities; and also on the health of people, which is already very vulnerable today.  We also draw attention to extreme weather conditions, which we are also seeing in Slovenia, which pose environmental, economic and safety risks especially to local communities. We demand that the incoming strategy take this into account and foresee appropriate measures and better mobilisation of resources. Our objectives are clear: by 2050, the EU should become a carbon neutral leader in the green economy and a role model for the world. However, we must meet the interim target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030.  When looking after the environment, let us be aware that greater ambition is always welcome. We only have one planet. Just this week, the Social Democrats also re-tabled a motion for a resolution declaring a climate and environmental emergency in the Republic of Slovenia in the Slovenian National Assembly. It is time for Slovenia to step aside from the 33 countries that already did so, as did the European Parliament last year, and take its future and the future of our children very seriously.

name: Guido REIL
text: Writing. At this sitting, Parliament called for a strong social Europe. How far is Parliament actually from reality? The tightened climate measures approved by the European Council will further undermine our prosperity, on which our social benefits are based. This policy is taking the energy-intensive industries into the fore and accelerating deindustrialisation. According to a study presented by the German Chamber of Commerce and Industry in September 2020, these new requirements will lead to a further tightening of the European emissions trading system. The high CO2 prices have a major impact on industrial companies, which are, after all, part of this emissions trading scheme. If only companies within the European Union have to bear these costs, there is a very high risk that these companies will relocate their activities. So there is a risk of losing these companies to Germany and Europe, and greenhouse gas emissions will not be reduced, they will only be relocated. The CO2 target as a driver, the one-sided focus on electric vehicles with the war against the internal combustion engine has serious consequences for our employment. The imposed change to an electric motor can only be financed with drastic austerity programs and fewer staff. EU climate policy is responsible for cutting thousands of jobs in industry. This is an anti-social policy.

text: Before continuing the debates and before today's first votes, I would like to give the floor to Representative Gabriele Bischoff, who asked to speak in accordance with Rule 159(4) of the Rules of Procedure, on her report: 'Amendment of the Rules of Procedure to ensure the functioning of Parliament in exceptional circumstances' (2020/2098(REG)) - Committee on Constitutional Affairs (A9-0194/2020).

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are voting today on the amendment of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. This amendment is necessary because we do not yet have a regulation for exceptional situations, and since the pandemic we have been in a difficult and also protracted exceptional situation. It is important that the functioning of the European Parliament is always guaranteed, because we are a special Parliament. This is where colleagues from 27 Member States come together, and it is precisely at the beginning of the pandemic that we have seen that we have faced particular challenges as a a whole due to travel restrictions and border closures. But parliaments, as places of political decision-making, must function. We have always managed to be open and actually capable of working in this pandemic, and I think we can be proud of that. The President and also the bodies have taken appropriate decisions to ensure that Parliament, as the heart of European democracy, remains open and functional. Since the outbreak of the pandemic, we in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs have been working together to draw up new proposals together, in order to be better prepared for future exceptional situations of all kinds. We have managed to reach a consensus across all political groups on four new rules of procedure, which are to be put to the vote today. With these rules, Parliament is also preparing itself for the digital way of working that we are currently experiencing, for rapid decision-making and for better legitimacy of these decisions. I would like to thank colleagues for their cooperative and constructive cooperation and recommend that we vote in favour of the report on the amendment of the Rules of Procedure. In doing so, we guarantee the citizens that Parliament remains fully operational in any exceptional situation and ensure that we can do our job at any time. That is why it is important that we adopt these rules in accordance with the Rules of Procedure.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, this dossier is a dossier, I think, extremely important and I am glad that we were able to complete it in a very short time, compared to the previous negotiation - it took two years, a year and a half compared to seven years. Many colleagues have worked on this dossier, I have taken this dossier from my colleague Ingeborg Grässle and I thank him for the work he has done in this dossier and, of course, also with the shadow rapporteurs. I think he managed to do, to bring the text to a very good version. Of course, we had as our main aim the collaboration between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and OLAF, but at the same time, on the basis of the European Parliament's proposals, we were able to introduce things that will facilitate and improve the work of OLAF: firstly, transparency within OLAF, access to files, but also access to bank accounts in the Member States. We have a controller, an independent structure in the supervisory committee, who will verify that procedural safeguards are correctly applied. We have procedures, higher standards of procedures for certain activities. At the same time, Member States are obliged to report on what they have done with the recommendations in the OLAF reports, so as to ensure the best possible collaboration between both Member States and institutions. I hope that now, through this OLAF-Public Prosecutor's Office collaboration, we will have a much better work in defence, in the fight against fraud with European funds. The dossier was voted on in the CONT Committee by a large majority and I hope that the same will happen in Parliament. I thank the Commissioner for cooperation and the Commissioner's cabinet, it was a very good collaboration and, at the same time, to OLAF for working very well with them and the two Croatian and German Presidencies.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am honoured to be here today to welcome the adoption of the revision of the OLAF Regulation, which sets the stage for the work of the Office in the years to come. As the rapporteur has already said, this marks the end of seven years of discussion and negotiations. I think it is worth mentioning this and stressing the energy that the current and previous rapporteurs put into these negotiations. Indeed, we had very intense and, ultimately, very fruitful negotiations on this significant piece of legislation. All the institutions showed commitment and resolve, and it has finally paid off.  I would like to thank the European Parliament and the Council for their work on this initiative. In particular, I would like to recognise the role of the rapporteur, Marian-Jean Marinescu. Marian-Jean, your determination to close the deal proved pivotal. I would also like to thank the co-rapporteurs who supported you in all your efforts.  The OLAF Regulation needed to be revised inter alia to adapt to the new anti-fraud architecture, which now also includes the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). However, the Regulation that we have ended up with achieves much more. We have strengthened the European Anti—Fraud Office, further equipping it with the tools it needs to protect the Union budget. A reformed OLAF is key to ensuring that the next European budget and the recovery plan are subject to the best control mechanism. The revised OLAF Regulation ensures cooperation between OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and reinforces OLAF’s investigative capacity. OLAF and the EPPO pursue the same objective of protecting the Union budget. While they do so within their own mandate, the revised OLAF Regulation ensures that they also do so in close cooperation. This cooperation relies on three pillars. First, the EPPO can rely on the support and expertise of OLAF in carrying out its tasks. Second, OLAF can launch investigations that are complementary to those of the EPPO to facilitate recovery or adopt administrative precautionary measures. Third, they exchange information before and during investigations through a mutual reporting mechanism. The reformed OLAF also has better tools to investigate fraud against the Union budget. It may access bank account information under the same conditions that apply to national competent authorities. It will conduct on-the-spot checks, pursuant to clearer rules, and benefit from an enhanced two-way cooperation with national authorities. These improvements go hand in hand with clearer procedural guarantees and the establishment of new functions to ensure their respect, like the Controller. To conclude, the Commission welcomes the revision of the OLAF Regulation, which contributes to shaping a revamped EU anti-fraud architecture. I am looking forward to hearing the views of the political groups. May I add that I think it was very timely to have this revision adopted in the light of the now much bigger European budget, with all the possible implications this will have on where we need to protect European taxpayers’ money. Therefore, I am grateful for your commitment and, finally, all of your achievements.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, rapporteur, Commissioner, fellow co-rapporteurs, if the next Politico publishes a ranking of the most influential politicians and Marian-Jean Marinescu is not there, I will stop taking it. Because he was the one who did so much work on this legislation. Marian-Jean, if I am not embarrassed, I will now kneel before you and all your colleagues, because you have passed legislation that has been in the works for seven years, with the help of the Commissioner, in a year and a half. And I am very proud that when I decided who I would entrust the news to as PPE coordinator, it was you, because really, Marian-Jean, you are one of the best MEPs we have in this building and in this room. In this report, Parliament has succeeded in several things – a supervisory body for procedural guarantees has been set up to oversee the inclusion of VAT. As a result, OLAF will also have access to bank accounts. However, it is now important that we concentrate on implementing the recommendations that OLAF is proposing. If we find that OLAF's recommendations have not been sufficiently taken into account and there has been no improvement in the situation, we will have to respond adequately to this. We must find other solutions to effectively combat financial fraud, irregularities, conflicts of interest and corruption. We cannot allow any systemic errors or vaguely set conditions, whether financial, legal or disciplinary checks. After all, it is our money and it is all taxpayers' money. Ladies and gentlemen, I wish you a blessed Christmas and all the best in the new year.

name: Tsvetelina PENKOVA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the Regulation on the EPPO has been adopted and must enter into force by 2020.  First, the EPPO is starting to function and it is essential that it has a seamless relationship with OLAF's office. Secondly, the renewed OLAF Regulation currently strengthens the institution's existing powers, while strengthening OLAF's ability to carry out an effective investigation with access, for example, to bank accounts and, thirdly, olaf must provide assurances and an update on the independence of the control body and stakeholders' access to the reports in the coming months.  I think we all understand why it is extremely important to strengthen OLAF's position by improving the effectiveness of legal stability in investigations. This will lead to comprehensive and more effective investigations. Member States' authorities should also not go beyond this process, but on the contrary, they need to start to make better use of olaf's investigative results, and this is key here, because only in this way will it be possible to prevent ongoing and future misuse of European funds.  Dear Colleagues, an unprecedented amount of additional funds will be allocated in the coming years to support the European economy, the green transition and all our strategies that we have developed in recent years. The additional funds will also be allocated to combat the consequences of the Kovid crisis, but control of the spending of these funds is key so that they can be spent really in the most effective way, and indeed reach out to European citizens and the most deprived.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, first of all, let me congratulate the colleagues in this House, in the Commission and in the Council for updating the European Anti—Fraud Office (OLAF) regulation and legally fine—tuning the working relations between the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) and OLAF. Now we have made the legal background ready for their effective functioning in the future. This is truly a great accomplishment. However, at the same time, in this discussion about the effectiveness of European anti—fraud efforts, let me highlight the very simple but still crucial concern: still insufficient funding. This may sound technical, but for my constituents it’s a painfully obvious problem. According to the latest report by OLAF, financial irregularities affect 4% of payments in Hungary. This is 10 times the EU average. But whenever I cite this number to my voters, they very often ask the question: wait a minute, only 4%? Then I explain that the capacity of OLAF only allows them to monitor a small fraction of payments – 5% or 10% – but in fact it is possible that this number is much higher, we just don’t know, and the fact that we don’t know is in itself very problematic. Now imagine that this already underfunded institution now has to administer EUR 750 billion in recovery funds. How can they do that?  We have also launched the European Public Prosecutor’s Office with really ground—breaking powers but, also in EPPO’s case, inadequate staffing and funding is still a problem. Let’s be clear: protecting our financial interests has costs. That’s a fact. But this cost is an investment in the future. It’s an investment in recovering this money, and spending more on anti—fraud operation is actually saving us money. So, let’s consider this in the future and let’s fight with every method possible for higher funding for these institutions in order for them to protect our European financial interests.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposed regulation we are discussing today aims to define how much of the pie will be left to OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office, after the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. At the same time, it strives to remedy the sometimes serious dysfunctions that have been observed in the operation of OLAF in recent years. The most attentive will remember that the main players in the fight against fraud in the European Union have not spared their criticism of the Office, be it the European Commission, our Parliament in its various landfills, the European Court of Auditors or the OLAF supervisory committee. While OLAF is theoretically supposed to carry out its investigations independently, the Court of Auditors did not fail to remind us, for example, that the professional promotion of its agents was carried out by the European Commission. Funny independence, really! In an excellent report, the French Parliament also concluded that the Agency could not claim to meet the rigorous criteria required of an independent administrative authority. I will thank you for the names of birds exchanged between the Agency and its oversight committee in recent years. The Agency's lack of consideration for its supervisory committee does not bode well for the serenity of future relations between OLAF and the European Data Protection Supervisor. It is promised, juror, spat: OLAF will stop making illegal wiretaps as in the case of the investigation against Commissioner Dalli, which resulted in the dismissal of its former director in Belgium. No more clandestine night searches of the offices of some MPs without their knowledge. The establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, while it clearly shows the abandonment of the sovereignty of national states, is also presented to us as a significant improvement in the rights of defence for those involved. Nothing is less certain in view of the totally disproportionate prerogatives granted to the Future Office: recognition of anonymous whistleblowers, the possibility for the Office, apart from any preliminary investigation or judicial information, to access the private telephone lines and bank accounts of agents and elected officials, actors of the Union , which revulded the highly respected Mrs Gressle, former chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Where is the rule of law? Before we lecture Poland, Hungary, the whole world, let's start by sweeping in front of our door! Some states refuse to go under the caudine forks of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Nationals of these countries will have fewer rights, in defiance of the eu's core values. Beautiful legal battles ahead.
