name: Daniel FREUND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, yesterday we approved the EU budget and the corona recovery funds – EUR 1.8 trillion of European solidarity. But, we have to be honest: some of this money will be stolen. If we, the European Union, are going to spend almost twice as much, we should at least double the budget of our anti-corruption bodies: the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) and the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). I honestly do not understand why, in this situation, you, Commissioner Hahn, have not approved the EUR 10 million in additional funding that the EPPO requested to properly function.  Maybe even more seriously, two thirds of the fraud that is uncovered by OLAF is simply ignored by the Member States. At this point in the EU version of Monopoly, we have to rename the Get Out of Jail Free card and call it the ‘Member States don’t cooperate with OLAF’ card. This has to stop. OLAF and the EPPO need to be properly funded and staffed. Member States urgently need to improve their cooperation with the anti-corruption bodies. Sweden, Ireland and Denmark need to join the European Public Prosecutor, because they are giving a cheap excuse to Poland and Hungary not to join. Finally, if Member States don’t cooperate with OLAF, we have to cut their funding under the Common Provisions Regulation, because it clearly means that the management and control systems are not working. It has to be clear: if EU money is stolen, we won’t let people get away with it.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The adoption of the regulation that we are discussing at the moment, on the European Public Prosecutor's Office, has made it necessary for the European Commission to update the legislation and to adapt the relevant European Union anti-fraud legislation accordingly, both with regard to expenditure and revenue of the European Union budget.  It was crucial to ensure that OLAF's new legal framework ensured that it could meet its statutory obligations without dugging its competences with the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as the implementation of areas vis-à-vis the European Public Prosecutor's Office of the Member States and the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. By introducing new solutions, OLAF would carry out investigations in a more effective and coherent way, thereby contributing to the effective protection of the budget across the Union. But there are some doubts here. The first is the possibility of violating the competences of the Member States, yet another is the possibility of duplicating, duplicating the powers of OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and national investigations. Nevertheless, the unclear role of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as the possibility of extending the powers of both bodies in the future, e.g. through Commission implementing acts.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, when we talk about this regulation today, we are talking about the division of work between OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office or the EPPO.  So far in many European countries, for example in Croatia, say Bulgaria, money has gone to feed the political regime that rules there and there is no effective control, nor has there been. We can only hope it's different now. This can be seen in Croatia, for example, in R&D competitions. The criterion by which money is awarded is pure luck, i.e. the method of the fastest finger. It's not the quality that matters, it's not any ranking list, it's whoever presses enter first, gets the development money. It doesn't matter if you have patents, if you brought them, it goes all to "mothers me, yes, I do, I'll bring them one day." And that's how it's awarded. There is a turbid water in which those who are close to politics and government swim very well. It's very important here how the prosecutor is e-elect. Unfortunately, he will be e-elect from the Croatian staff, they will be integrated into USKOK, cases will be raised, indictments before our courts, the Zagreb County Court and the money will be barely for salaries.  The only thing that remains remains for us to hope and believe in the moral integrity of Laura Kovesi because we will once again return to the Croatian judicial staff as well as the case of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, I'm afraid.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The adoption of the budget is of historic importance, several times, because, in addition to the enormous responsibility for planning and adopting each budget cycle, dramatic circumstances have intervened this year, as well as the pandemic. An aid package of unprecedented size in the history of the Union had to be adopted together with the multiannual budget, while the European Union took a huge step towards protecting our common values and finances. This was the adoption of conditions of the rule of law linked to payments. In order for everything to be done in the Member States of the Union in accordance with EU law and its core values, it is essential to have an effective EU investigating authority and public prosecutor's office. This is especially true when we are discussing our common finances and using our common money. Unfortunately, in recent years, we have been able to list in number an in number of cases, Hungary, Poland, or even the Czech Republic, where governments and heads of government have been incited against the Union by running through EU values, dethrecing the rule of law and stealing EU money, while holding their hands for EU money. However, this is now over. Finally, the rule of law mechanism, OLAF and the EU Public Prosecutor's Office can jointly stop unscrupulous theft. However, it is essential to coordinate the functioning of OLAF and the EU Public Prosecutor's Office. There is a need to expand OLAF's investigative powers, and it is also important to strengthen OLAF's rights in the proceedings of the person involved in the investigation, for example. Let us also strengthen the protection of procedural guarantees by establishing a post of procedural auditor. In addition to the functioning of the rule of law mechanism, OLAF and the Public Prosecutor's Office can work together effectively, so that the citizens of Europe can be calmer and safer with their own money, their finances, Europe's money. The successful cooperation between OLAF and the Public Prosecutor's Office is worth making a serious effort. As with all the work, it is now a great pleasure to have the rule of law mechanism, for the same reason it is important to establish this excellent cooperation between OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to effectively defend European values and European interests.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Today we are talking about the fight against fraud, in particular cooperation between the two authorities OLAF – the former anti-fraud authority – and the newly created EPPO, the Public Prosecutor's Office. The fight against fraud is essential. Why is this so important? Well, as a good European, you certainly know Dante's "Divine Comedy." Dante is astonished when, during his visit to the Inferno, he finds people in the deepest circle of hell, namely – frozen into the eternal ice – fraudsters and traitors: Brutus and also Judas Iscariot.  Are fraud and betrayal so bad? Yes, because fraudsters and traitors destroy the most important element of human coexistence: trust in the good will of one's neighbour. And that is why it is essential to identify fraudsters and bring them to justice.  However, I see at least two problems in the cooperation between olaf and EPPO: the rate of fraud to the national authorities has already been less than 30%. Why do you think that this quota will actually improve when a new authority is added and when there are many more competency wrangling than before? Nor is it good that the EPPO is withdrawing staff and know-how from OLAF, thereby weakening the fight against fraud to date. In the first PIF report 31 years ago, the Commission said that cooperation between the authorities involved is a success factor. That is the most important thing.  You may not want to listen to me now, I am a lonely caller in the desert. But if you do not listen to me on this matter, at least in this Advent season, listen to the voices of the prophets of the Old Covenant and prepare your hearts to meet Jesus Christ—the coming—and to receive the Savior of the world into your hearts.

name: Sabrina PIGNEDOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new OLAF regulation has become necessary in order to adapt the legal framework following the establishment of EPPO and to determine its reports. But this Parliament has done even more, and I am satisfied with the outcome of these negotiations, because it has been possible to maintain OLAF's independence and strengthen its investigation procedures. In fact, the follow-up system for recommendations between OLAF and the Member States has been improved. For olaf investigations, the figure of the controller has been set up, which will monitor the procedures to ensure its correctness and provision has been made for the possibility for suspects to have access to the final report, all of which are steps in the direction we want. The introduction of the possibility for OLAF to control bank accounts and initiate VAT controls is also excellent.  There is still room for improvement. For example, the controller should be a more independent figure with more powers. In addition, the procedure for accessing documents must be simpler. The budgetary problem for EPPO and OLAF and the fact that OLAF investigations must also be carried out by the Member States remain clearly the problem.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I think we really can say that the European Parliament has profoundly influenced the revision of this OLAF Regulation. You have supported all the Commission proposals to strengthen the effectiveness of investigations, as well as our objective to base the relationship between OLAF and the EPPO on the strongest complementarity.  In addition, you have pushed to ensure that OLAF’s strong investigative tools co—exist with stronger procedural guarantees. In fact, the revised legislation establishes a controller to handle complaints by persons concerned. It allows the person under investigation to assess the final report under certain conditions and provides for respect of higher procedural safeguards when OLAF supports the EPPO.  These amendments should increase the protection of persons subject to investigation and also increase the reliability of OLAF’s work even though the rules on admissibility of OLAF—collected evidence in subsequent criminal procedures will go unchanged. We should soon start implementing a new financial framework accompanied by an ambitious recovery plan. It’s crucial that the Union will be ready to protect European Union citizens’ money, ensuring that money is spent properly and effectively.  Having said this, also in response to Mr Freund and others, I think we have now provided the necessary financial means to the different organisations. In particular, we constantly hear that the EPPO should get more money. I think even before they start working they have the same staff numbers as OLAF, because you have to include the decentralised prosecutors and then you certainly arrive at the same number. And may I say that the original concept of the EPPO was to focus very much on the work of the decentralised prosecutors, but now we see a very strong headquarters.  Again, I think we should see how it works, how it comes into operational daily work and then, of course, we have to adapt to the needs and see what are the future needs. I was very clear in the discussions. There are opportunities like amending budgets, etc., where we can, so to say, react in case there are further needs.  But first, I think, we should now really pay attention so that the EPPO can finally start – as soon as possible, hopefully in spring – its work, and then I think we can have a further assessment about the future needs.  Please be assured that we have every interest not only to protect our money, but also to get it back in the case of fraud and criminal cases. So indeed – and I think this was said by Ms Cseh and others – this is something which should really pay off in the way that we get the money back. Both these institutions, but also others dealing with such issues, are indeed properly equipped, because they need it. We will certainly take care that at the end of the day we get the money back – and certainly more than we have to invest into the staffing and the financing of these institutions. But on the other hand, we have to see that everything is in balance and we really lead also by example.  Finally, we are talking today primarily about OLAF and that’s why I would again like to highlight that the revised OLAF Regulation is a key element of the new EU Anti—Fraud architecture that we are building to achieve that objective. This is not only about the cooperation between OLAF and EPPO. Here, of course, it’s about the investigative and prosecutorial powers of EPPO which are now there, but we should not forget there is also Europol, and its analytical capacity has to be used. The same applies to Eurojust, which definitely has a coordinating role. So the reformed OLAF is a centrepiece, if you like, of this architecture to carry out even more effective  investigations.  What we have to achieve is proper coordination, cooperation amongst all these institutions. It’s not only about the two, and we should not forget Europol and Eurojust and cooperation with these organisations so as to have complementarity and avoid overlapping. This also would contribute to more effectiveness of these European institutions and instruments.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: With regard to the Marinescu report, no proposals have been tabled to reject the Council's position and no amendments have been tabled pursuant to Rules 67 and 68 of the Rules of Procedure. The draft legislative act is therefore deemed to have been adopted. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. As Europol has pointed out, organised crime is already working to try to exploit the many opportunities offered by the Recovery Fund and the various European Structural Funds envisaged, in support of the Member States, to deal with the pandemic crisis. In this alarming context, the European Union must equip itself with effective law enforcement agencies, and the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). In the fight against fraud, to the detriment of the Union's budget, it is certainly a fundamental stage in the European anti-fraud architecture. Consequently, it was equally crucial to update Regulation No 883/2013, which regulates the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF), whose task is to investigate illegal behaviour such as fraud and corruption, which are often the first step in more composite criminal designs, to the detriment of the Union budget. Thanks to the efforts made in the complex negotiations, which I have had the honour of following personally, I can say with satisfaction that the new regulatory framework extending OLAF's legal basis, increasing its powers of investigation, will ensure close cooperation, exchange of information and complementarity of investigations with the European Public Prosecutor's Office, but will also represent a significant step, in the further consolidation of the rule of law, in the European Area of Freedom, Security and Justice.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report (A9-0263/2020) by Kosma Złotowski, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the issues dealt with by the Committee on Petitions in 2019 (2020/2044(INI)). Members are informed that no requestable speeches will be given during this part-session and that blue card questions will not be accepted. I would also like to point out that the speeches can be spoken remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: Rapporteur. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The Committee on Petitions plays a special role in the work of our Parliament. This is the only forum where the citizens of the European Union can not only present their problems and the challenges they face, but, most importantly, speak in person at committee meetings. It is always invaluable for democracy when victims can tell their own story of their plight. We all the more regret that this difficult year has deprived us of the opportunity to meet petitioners in personal.  PETI is also the most interdisciplinary of all committees. The programme of its activities is constantly laid out by the petitioners themselves, who apply to us. Among the most frequently discussed topics in 2019 were environmental issues, transport, the protection of children's rights, the difficulties of people with disabilities and the so many concerns on both sides of the Brexit channel. The number of petitions submitted compared to 2018 increased by more than 11%. More petitions have also been declared admissible. Unfortunately, more than 30% of petitions still did not refer directly to the competence or area of activity of the European Union, which means that they could not be dealt with. Citizens' lack of knowledge of the division of competences between Brussels and the Member States is a challenge to the process of discussing and responding to petitions, which we must deal with in the coming years. Cooperation with other parliamentary committees is a key element in the efficiency and effectiveness of the work taken by the Committee on Petitions. In 2019, 65 petitions were sent to other committees for opinions and 351 were sent to them for information. The contribution and expertise of colleagues from other committees are therefore necessary in order to fully respond to petitioners' questions and requests.  Among the important initiatives that have been indirectly inspired by petitioners to the European Parliament is the proposal for a directive on the abolition of seasonal time changes and the repeal of Directive 2000/84. The Committee on Petitions has prepared an opinion on the report on this issue, which has been based on numerous reports from citizens calling for this burdensome obligation to be removed. It is also important to highlight the large number of Brexit petitions submitted in 2019, which were largely concerned with protecting the rights of EU citizens before and after the UK's exit. The Committee on Petitions has done a very good job here and its actions have made citizens' rights one of Parliament's main priorities in the negotiations between Brussels and London.  Summing up the work of the Committee on Petitions in 2019, we should mention two institutions that play a very important role in the process of responding and responding to petitions. This is, of course, the European Commission, which is using our knowledge in hearings and discussions with petitioners, but the European Ombudsman is particularly thanked. The best proof that this collaboration works exemplary was the re-election of Emily O'Reilly to the post last December. It was the Committee on Petitions that was responsible for the process of analysing and hearing all candidates.  2019 has been a challenging year for the work of the Committee on Petitions due to a break in our work related to the elections and the period of the new composition of Parliament. However, I am convinced that the time we had at our disposal was very good. This is, of course, due to our President Dolores Montserrat and the commitment of all the members of the committee, but also to the professionalism of the staff of our secretariat, to whom we owe a huge thank you. I hope that Parliament will also give a positive assessment of their work and adopt the report presented on the activities of the Committee on Petitions for the previous year.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I thank the rapporteur, Mr Złotowski, for this comprehensive report, which will contribute to further strengthening relations between the Commission and the Committee on Petitions (PETI). As discussed during our structured dialogue two weeks ago, we are constantly working to improve our cooperation. I strongly believe the ability to petition is a fundamental right for all citizens and a key element of parliamentary democracy. Today, more than ever against the backdrop of the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, petitions are an effective channel for direct contact and open dialogue concerning problems affecting the daily lives of Europeans. Even before the pandemic, the use of petitions was on the increase, up by 11.23% in 2019 compared to the previous year. This was due in part to the more visible and accessible European Parliament Petitions Web Portal. Many of the petitions were in the environmental, health and social sectors. Let me assure you that the Commission takes the work of this committee very seriously. We continue our efforts to improve the speed, quality and pertinence of our contributions to your replies to petitioners’ concerns. This includes the modernisation of our IT tools for handling petitions and streamlining the underlying procedures. In addition, the Commission is increasingly represented at your meetings by Commissioners and high-ranking officials, especially when it comes to sensitive petitions. To put it in numbers, in the first year of our mandate, two Commissioners, three directors-general, four deputy directors-general, 10 directors and 22 heads of unit participated in debates in the PETI Committee. This trend will continue in the coming year. I take note of the section of your report on the issue of petitions and infringement procedures. As you know, the primary purpose of the infringement procedure is to make sure that Member States comply with EU law. It cannot be used to alter the specific legal situation of an individual or provide for individual means of redress. Therefore, we believe that individual complaints pointing to the incorrect application of EU law are often better addressed by the appropriate mechanisms at national level. This approach leaves the Commission more able to focus its resources on addressing systemic issues. I can assure you that we remain fully committed to fruitful cooperation in addressing infringement-related petitions. In this spirit, the Commission welcomes the Committee’s opinion on identifying potential systemic breaches of EU law with the petitions it receives. However, the decision on whether or not to investigate and pursue an instance of suspected non-compliance with EU law must remain within the Commission’s discretionary power. The Commission holds the burden of proof in bringing cases before the Court of Justice, and it must focus its efforts on issues that will bring the most benefit to EU citizens. I stress that, where petitions are not within the remit of the European Union, we should be very honest and upfront in explaining this to petitioners.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to express my thanks to my colleague Kosma Zotowski and the other shadow rapporteurs for the good cooperation on this report. Together, we have managed to produce an objective report that has not been unnecessarily politicised, and the work of the committee in 2019 is very well reflected. Petitions are signs of an adult democracy. Any citizen, whatever his social status, can complain without fear about problems in the practical application of Union law. Petitions are, so to speak, a seismograph of the mood of the population and, at the same time, an instrument of control, which helps to strengthen the transparency and accountability of the institutions. It is difficult to be closer to the citizen than to the Committee on Petitions in the day-to-day running of Parliament. Parliament received 1 357 petitions in 2019. This shows that EU citizens and residents of the European Union have continued to exercise the right of petition, despite the break in the session for the European elections. The number of users who supported one or more petitions on Parliament's internet portal for petitions has actually increased compared to 2018 and has reached a total of 28 075, which is extremely pleasing. What can we do better? It is somewhat regrettable that petitioners are still not sufficiently informed of the reasons for the inadmissibility of a petition. This can be a learning process for both sides: for us, but also, above all, for the petitioner. The citizen can learn from this what he can do better next time.  That is why a continuous public debate on the Union's areas of activity is essential in order to raise public awareness of the right of petition to the European Parliament. There should therefore also be an active press and communication service and an active presence on the social media of the Committee on Petitions in order to increase the visibility of the committee's work. It is up to us to process the petitions as soon as possible and to respond appropriately. And this is especially true when the citizens have turned to the wrong place. It is not always clear to the citizen whether his problem concerns regional, national or EU level. In this case, the Committee on Petitions must better communicate and cooperate with the national authorities, petitions committees and ombudsmen. All in all, I would like to thank the secretariat of the Committee on Petitions and my colleagues for the work they have done. I wish everyone a Merry Christmas and a Healthy New Year. And as I always say elsewhere: there is still a lot to do, let's tackle it!

name: Cristina MAESTRE MARTÍN DE ALMAGRO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Article 227 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides, as one of the fundamental rights of citizens, with the capacity to exercise their right of petition before this House on matters affecting them at European Union level.  This gives enormous value to the Committee on Petitions, which is an instrument of citizen empowerment and is also a democratic instrument that defends the European values that inspire the Union. And it certainly also gives us the opportunity to learn more about the problems of citizens.  Therefore, we must strongly defend the value of the Committee on Petitions and do so without undermining any rights, giving fair audiences to citizens by virtue of the rules we have given ourselves, serving as a platform or amplifier for the voices of those who are not always heard, those who are not cared for, those who suffer injustices or inequalities by negligence or indifference. And we have to do it in a weighted way, adjusted to objective criteria and not to the albur of other tactical interests that all they can achieve is to harm European citizens.  This House has approved important measures, the result of citizen petitions. As an example, very relevant, the Resolution on additional funding for biomedical research of myalgic encephalomyelitis, the result of a request made in 2019 by the affected persons themselves. We have also managed to stop abuses by some airlines or other abuses in the area of infringement of European workers' rights. We have also put the batteries in institutions, administrations. And, in this respect and finally, I would like to thank the European Commission for her work and extend my thanks to Commissioner Dalli, also for her involvement. And I even want to ask you a little more to be able to further expedite the processing of certain requests that require urgency. Thank you, too, to the colleagues and services of the House for their annual work.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We write the PETI annual report not only to present data, but above all to learn from it. The most frequent topics of the petitions were again last year environment, fundamental rights and justice. These are therefore issues on which we must attach particular importance. We also see that 30% of petitions are still considered inadmissible. On the one hand, this shows that many citizens do not know in which areas the EU is working and that we need to provide information here. However, it also shows great confidence and hope in the European Parliament when the citizens turn to us with problems of all kinds. We must live up to this trust; we must not abuse this trust. The Committee on Petitions is a bridge between citizens and decision-makers. It would therefore be useful to involve the Committee on Petitions directly in the legislative process, so that the good knowledge of the petitions is not lost.  Furthermore, the Committee on Petitions does not deal exclusively with petitions, but also, in some cases, with European citizens' initiatives, and it is important that they are taken seriously. Collecting one million signatures from at least seven Member States is an important matter in which many citizens have expectations of the European Union. If the elected representatives of the people from the European Parliament also support this proposal, then the Commission should see this as a clear mandate to present a legislative proposal on this. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Kosma Zaotowski, and all my colleagues for their cooperation, and I would ask you to support this successful report without any further amendments. Thank you!

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Greens/ European Free Alliance Group fully supports the report as voted on in the Committee on Petitions. As already mentioned, precisely our priorities on environmental matters and fundamental rights are the topics where we have received the most petitions. One word on petitions on fundamental rights: to our regret, the famous Article 51 of the Charter on Fundamental Rights says it is applicable only as regards EU law and, therefore, we are very satisfied that the report urges the Commission to take steps to ensure that the interpretation of the scope of Article 51 is as coherent and broad as possible, and recalls that the expectations of most petitioners in relation to the rights conferred on them by the Charter are high and go beyond the current scope of application.  Another key problem is the European citizens’ initiative. We know that there are very few successful petitions and that is why the latest one we discussed this Monday on the Minority Safepack was very important. However, regrettably, even successful petitions do not result in legislative proposals from the Commission. The report also mentions this problem. We call on the Commission to initiate a legislative proposal on the basis of any successful European citizens’ initiatives that are supported by the European Parliament.  To our regret, two large groups in Parliament have asked for a split vote on this proposal and this sentence, as it is very troublesome. If this statement does not make it into the report as voted on by the Committee on Petitions, this will be a big mistake. I repeat – as mentioned in the report – only 43% of EU citizens trust the European Union. This is a very bad number and if we just dismiss the most important applications made to Parliament, that is the European citizens’ initiatives bearing more than one million signatures, representing at least seven Member States, this will be a big failure.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I cannot take this stand without first denouncing that in Spain a new attack on the life and dignity of the human being will be perpetrated by the adoption of a cruel and inhumane law such as the law of euthanasia, the law of death.  This year it will also go down in the history of the Committee on Petitions for the ignominy of having seen certain parliamentary groups in this House oppose the clarification of 379 murders produced by the ETA terrorist gang, separatist and far-left, even those who are part of the Government of Spain and have a duty to defend the memory , dignity, truth and justice for all victims.  The course has also ended with another petition pleading with the European Parliament to unravel one of the biggest political scandals, which is the possible existence of a criminal network for the abuse and sexual harassment of children protected in centres run by the Administration in the Balearic Islands.  Because all victims matter, because violence is genderless, we will continue to vigilant to unmask the hypocrisy of all groups that tear their garments off in the face of false violence, yet cowards and accomplices are silent when violence is real and causes death and desolation.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we are generally satisfied with the agreed text, as it reflects for the most part what the Committee on Petitions did in 2019.  However, it is clear and notorious that there remains among citizens about the scope of the right of petition, its mechanisms and the competences of the Union, as well as the need for the Committee on Petitions to adopt a more powerful communication strategy.  We also welcome the text's need for the European Citizens' Initiative to be considered for participation, as well as the call for it to be a much more dynamic and attractive mechanism for groups and citizens in general.  And, since we are talking about mechanisms of participation and direct democracy, I would like to take this opportunity to highlight the need for stateless nations in Europe to establish a European framework for free exercise and with guarantees of their right to decide their future.  Finally, the report does not contain one of the requests that has generated the greatest demand and controversy: the denial of its right to be members of this House suffered by Catalan MES, a right which this committee has repeatedly denied. It is one of the best examples of the excessive political hand in the decision to close or keep open petitions, especially in this new legislature.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I congratulate my colleague Zlotowski on the report. In fact, it describes in detail the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2019. I call on you to vote in favour of this report, in particular Paragraph 29, which calls for the European Commission to make legislative proposals on the basis of successful European citizens' initiatives supported by the European Parliament. We listen to the words of the citizens, and if that word is strong, then we must carry on. That's why we were elected. I also think it is important, looking to the future, that the activities of the Committee on Petitions should not only consist of making proposals for solutions to petitions submitted by citizens and acting on them. Let us also place greater emphasis on the effective implementation of our own resolutions in the future. I will give you an example: The report on the Ombudsman's activities in 2018, voted on at the end of 2019, states that the Ombudsman should examine the anomalies experienced in hearing European Commissioners. Unfortunately, no progress has been made on this issue since then. By better monitoring our own achievements, we can also improve the efficiency of the commission's work.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the rapporteur and also, in particular, the socialist shadow rapporteur, my colleague and friend Cristina Maestre Martín de Almagro, for their excellent work in this report on the deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2019.  This has already been said, but it should be reiterated: the right of petition is one of the fundamental rights of the citizens of the Union and is a key element in the empowerment of European citizenship and civil society , also organised, and for the political strengthening of Parliament within the framework of the European institutions.  One fact in this report should be underlined: in 2019, despite the coronavirus pandemic, the number of requests increased by more than 11% compared to the previous year, in matters as important as the environment, Brexit or the exercise of rights or disability.  This highlights the issues that matter and concern citizens, who are also calling for greater action by the European Union. The Commissioner said so: there are areas where the European Union has no competence, but when citizens call for action, they are also sending a political message about what the European Union would also have to start working on. And, in this regard, it seems to me that the Conference on the Future of Europe is the area for reflecting on what new powers the European Union should exercise.  Commissioner, you know this: before the pandemic, no one thought of Europe as the framework for action against public health crises, and now we have launched the Health Union under Article 168 of the Treaty. But we can go further.  The work of the Committee on Petitions denounces non-compliance and bad practices of the Member States, and in this regard we must also remind the Commission and the European Council of the obligation to respect the literality of Articles 15 and 17 of the Treaty on European Union.

name: Jarosław DUDA
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, I would like to thank and congratulate Colleague Złotowski for preparing such a comprehensive report, in which he aptly highlighted all aspects of the Committee on Petitions' work and the challenges ahead. The Committee on Petitions is one of the few to have direct contact with citizens. Therefore, its smooth and efficient operation is crucial for the image of the European Parliament and for building trust in the European institutions. Over the past year, we have been able, in cooperation with our partners, not only to consider many petitions, but also to bring about legislative and political action.  The Committee on Petitions, listening to the voice of citizens, carefully examines all their expectations in this regard. Environmental and health issues have been particularly important over the past year. Preventing environmental pollution, reducing waste, preventing diseases associated with harmful substances contained in food, soil, air or drinking water are key issues for Europeans.  Another important issue is respect for the rights of persons with disabilities and the creation of conditions for full access by this group of citizens to inclusive education, counselling, employment, civil rights and cultural goods. The Committee on Petitions advocates the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and an effective European Disability Strategy for the coming years. I hope that, if the pandemic situation allows, we will host the fifth European Parliament of Persons with Disabilities next year.  Thanking the European Commission very much for its cooperation, I would like to ask that, in the future, the answers to the petitioners be prepared as soon as possible and, even more importantly, that they are not vague, but accurately respond to complaints and questions. I would like to support the rapporteur's recommendations for greater involvement of the communication services in promotional and information campaigns.  Finally, I would like to thank the whole Parliament (inable words) and the various political groups for their tireless work and commitment. Thank you so much! Healthy and merry Christmas!

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is important that Europeans see how seriously we take their concerns. Our close cooperation can ensure that this is indeed the case. We are committed to continuing to provide detailed responses to petitions and possible solutions at European or national level. This is a concrete example of how we can collaborate to strengthen citizens’ confidence and trust in the European project.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the deterioration of the human rights situation in Egypt, in particular the case of the activists of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR) (2020/2912(RSP)*. I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted.  It also provides for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States. ___________

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Madam President, do not count how many times we have really condemned Egypt's dictatorship and human rights violations in this House. But as we condemn this dictatorship, in Egypt it continues to be suppressed, it continues to be tortured, everyone who thinks differently is made to disappear.  And as this happens, your president visits and strolls through all the red carpets in Europe. While murdering European citizens, such as Giulio Regeni, they imprison defenders, such as Patrick Zaki, who was studying in Europe by the way, Al-Sisi receives the highest distinctions from Macron. I don't know if I'd consider it an example or it was just a business issue. Business like trump has done with his favorite dictator, Al-Sisi, who kills his people. But countries like Spain, such as France or Italy ignore international provisions and continue to sell him weapons and equipment to suppress his people. And this is intolerable. But look, then we say we're the great defenders of human rights. What we are is great hypocrites.  We demand the freedom of Patrick Zaki, Ramy Shaat and all political prisoners, that European cooperation be directed only to support civil society and that agreements with a dictatorship like Egypt's be cancelled. Fewer words, more deeds.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Author. Madam President, the Identity and Democracy Group has tabled an alternative resolution on human rights in Egypt. At the time of this resolution, we were sure that we would not find a common resolution; we knew that we would find a form of ignorance, if not contempt. Ignorance, first of all, in the face of the dangers that the two elections of President Sissi have allowed to fight. Colleagues, be certain, Egypt is doing much better with President Sissi at the helm. Remember the situation when Mr. Mohamed Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood ruled the country. In fact, we have learned that the European Commission has funded associations such as the Collective against Islamophobia in France, so we are entitled to ask a question: when will the European Union finally become aware of the dangers associated with the organisation of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, as in some countries of our continent?  Ignorance, then, of what Egyptian society is. Illiteracy, extreme poverty, undermining work by some Islamic preachers are the real emergencies facing the Egyptian state. To suggest that President Sissi's obsession would be to repress human rights activists is, in my opinion, totally untrue. Finally, ignorance of the importance of Egypt in the fight against Islamism. To counter the influence of Qatar and Turkey on the Mediterranean world and on Muslims, we need to work with Cairo in confidence. Colleagues, this resolution condemns a state that is trying to improve its relationship with the Coptic community, which is fighting Islamism on its soil. It is shocking, inappropriate, counterproductive and we will not vote for it. I take this opportunity to wish a merry Christmas to the Coptic community of Egypt who, thanks to President Sissi, can celebrate it in peace.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after what I have just heard, I want to say to some Republicans in France that when you have the same friends as the far right, it is never very good.  I expect this resolution to be taken into account and to advance the human right, so severely undermined in Egypt, with its tens of thousands of political prisoners, these journalists, lawyers, human rights activists arbitrarily imprisoned, with this ruthless repression. We are talking about broken, suppressed lives, separated families and unbearable injustices. Who would deny here that Egypt is simply a dictatorship?  And yet, helplessly, we witnessed in France the welcome with great pomp of President al-Sissi. I'm outraged. I am appalled that our French President is thus honouring the violation of international law. I am appalled that he officially refuses to condition the reception of a head of state on his respect for human rights. In doing so, Mr Macron makes it clear that anyone, no matter what he does, will be worthy of france's membership and denigrates all the work done by the European Union to enforce the rights of Egyptians. It's a disgrace. As I said, I expect this resolution to advance rights in Egypt. But I also expect it to move us Europeans forward, because it is highly time that we measured the effects of our financing and trade policies with this regime. It is also time for sanctions to fall. Amnesty International's reports are edifying on human rights violations.  Why do our governments tolerate these crimes? On behalf of the French and German armaments industries. On behalf of the French and German industries, to sell 700 million weapons, President Macron last week awarded a dictator our Legion of Honor and ignored the suffering of his people. This armament, moreover, ends up in the hands of the repressive security forces. When will this industry be controlled and transparent? Mr Macron, again, is organising himself so as not to have to answer for his responsibilities. This is a disgrace, and Europe must remedy it.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from this Parliament today we say very clearly and decisively that we no longer tolerate the continuing violation of human rights in Egypt and, also because of our great friendship with the Egyptian people, that we cannot stand by and watch.  More than 60 000 people are being held for political reasons, in a climate of systematic repression of all forms of dissent and freedom. And that's enough! We believe that the international community, the European institutions and the Member States must react with great unity. The European Union must demand the immediate release of Patrick Zaki, a young citizen who went to university in Bologna, Europe, imprisoned without explanation for more than 300 days, and with him the release of all those who, like him, are unjustly imprisoned for their opinions, for their work, for the expression of their thoughts, for their sexual orientation.  We demand that justice be done to the murder of Giulio Regeni, a European citizen who was the victim of shocking, senseless violence, and that the Italian justice system be upholded, which has opened a trial against four Egyptian service agents, despite their many attempts at misreach.  From here, from the European Parliament, we express our utmost solidarity with Giulio Regeni's parents, and I personally also fully agree with the request to recall the Italian Ambassador they have made. Europe, in line with its principles and values, cannot afford hessebancy. This also applies to European governments. That is why we say that targeted sanctions must be applied against Egyptian officials guilty of violence, diplomatic relations with Egypt must be radically reviewed, arms sales must be suspended and any dangerously ambiguous attitude towards al-Sisi must be avoided, such as President Macron's absurd and astonishing decision to give him the Legion of Honour, which has nothing to do with our values.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Egypt is free. In the Freedom Index, the country is in third last place, ladies and gentlemen. And the situation is difficult for human rights activists, journalists and lawyers. These people are simply declared terrorists and imprisoned. This is unacceptable and here in the European Parliament we call on the Egyptian Government to release all those who are simply arrested indiscriminately. In particular, we are calling for the release of Patrick Zaki, and we are calling – and I agree with my colleagues from the S&D – for the case of Giulio Regeni to be clarified and for those who committed this act to be brought to justice. name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I was in Egypt, also as a member of the delegation of the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs. It is a great country, and it is in our interest to stabilise it so that the people of Egypt choose the future precisely in their homeland and not seek happiness in Europe.  Of course, the European Union has the instruments to exert pressure, such as humanitarian and charitable aid or the European Investment Bank. In a word, it is about financial pressure. We can apply it in such a way that human rights are respected there and, as is worth mentioning, the rights of Christians, because it has often been the case that the authorities have looked at discrimination against Christians without any response. I call for solidarity with our brothers and women in the faith in this country and for respect for human rights in Egypt.

name: Christian SAGARTZ
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Human rights are an important issue for the European Parliament. Who, if not us, should speak out for those people around the world who cannot defend themselves and stand up for their rights? However, I would also like to make it quite clear that today's debate is about a concrete initiative – the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights – where three activists have been imprisoned, are in pre-trial detention and are obviously being prevented from doing their work – in their important work for civil society, for the whole of Egypt. And it is up to us as parliamentarians to draw attention once again today to the fact that we are backing such initiatives. However, I would like to make it very clear on my group that we also see the importance of Egypt as a partner. The European Union sees Egypt as a partner, especially in the fight against terrorism. And I would also like to make this clear here: in addition to the justified critical points that previous speakers have said, and the sharpness of the resolution – this aspect is deliberately brought here – I would like to say that there are also positive aspects in cooperation with Egypt. The key lies in this partnership. However, a partnership must not be blind. We must not be blind in one eye and look at the other. That would not fit, nor does it fit the European Union, and that is why it is quite clear that the PPE-DE is calling here for human rights to be respected, for prisoners to be wrongly freed and for the rights of the people of Egypt to be safeguarded by those in power. However, I would just like to say that we, too, have similar problems within Europe and at our borders. I am thinking only of the discussions, of the demonstrations in Belarus, and I believe that it is our task and our obligation to be very precise here. What do I mean by that? Article 144, which is the basis of today's debate, refers to cases of violations of human rights. And I would like to say here on my group that the length of the resolutions and also the balance of the resolutions are of course important if we want to raise our voices together, if we want to send a strong signal here across the political groups. And that is what I would have liked from this resolution. Egypt has the potential to serve as a bridge to the Arab world and africa, and it is up to us to initiate a functioning civil society, a functioning coexistence of economic systems and, as European institutions, to continue to advance as we can. And I believe that we must focus very sharply on respect for human rights here – especially as parliamentarians, that is our obligation. However, we must not forget the balance here too. And I believe that it is highly necessary to focus on partnership in common interests in at least the same way as all the other efforts and all the other issues that have been raised today in a justified and very clear way.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, overall, the EU has very good relationship with our southern neighbour, Egypt. The EU has displayed a strong commitment to continue its common work with Egypt in areas of crucial importance for the Egyptian people such as environment, energy and water management. Nevertheless, it is because of this common work that we must express our concern over the deteriorating situation of human rights in Egypt. The Egyptian government must comply with all national and international legislation when it comes to the protection and advancement of human rights. Without the impartial rule of law, you cannot have well-functioning civil society, especially in countries where we hear of repeated reports of intimidation and prosecution of civil rights activists, journalists and other NGOs. I join the calls on the Egyptian government to pursue domestic reforms to protect civil right activists, journalists, as well as their families. This is clearly needed, as is evidenced by Egypt’s poor record of media freedom and the high number of imprisoned journalists. The fact that the director and several senior managers of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights have been arrested in Cairo are of significant concern. Therefore, the EU and this House will strongly convey a message to the Egyptian authorities that this is unacceptable. Egypt is an important neighbour and partner but our friendship cannot be sustained if the significant and legitimate human rights concerns are not addressed. For that reason, we appeal to Egypt today to heed our petition and to address these immediately so that our good relationship can continue, otherwise it will go backwards.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, when in January 2011 the Egyptian youth had mobilized for weeks in Tahrir Square, they were seeking to free themselves from a police state, from a regime of oppression that left no hope, no prospects for that future. Ten years later, unfortunately, only the face of the Egyptian regime has changed while the reality of human rights is deteriorating by the day. While President al-Sissi has received the honours of some European states, the Egyptian population is subject to an unprecedented repression in the history of modern Egypt. Detentions, executions, enforced disappearances and torture are now commonplace in Egypt. Since Mr. al-Sissi came to power in 2013, the country has plunged into total repression. Journalists, lawyers, trade unionists, activists, human rights defenders: NGOs estimate that Egyptian prisons hold more than 60,000 prisoners of conscience. Recently, senior officials of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights were detained simply because they met with European diplomats in Cairo. The European Union and member states must respond in a united and resolute way to combat human rights violations in Egypt. The recent sanctioning tool that has been accepted must be able to be activated against those who today violate human rights in Egypt. The European Union must be with the Egyptian people and not with the Egyptian regime.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, "I missed the opportunity to take my exams for the second semester. Honestly it's one of the problems I'm most concerned about. I want to send a love to my colleagues from the University of Bologna, Granada and Seville." This has not been written from a home, from a house, but from a prison, from Tora Prison. He is Patrick Zaki, an Erasmus student, who has been in prison for three hundred days. He was arrested when he went to see his parents. He could be my son; could be my daughter, the daughter of any of you.  I am talking about Patrick Zaki because it is the best way for us to see today the face of the Al-Sisi regime, an increasingly darker, crueler regime that uses repression and considers Erasmus students of gender issues, such as Patrick Zaki, bloggers, singers, journalists, human rights defenders...  This has to stop: it's not acceptable.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her To get to the specific issue we are dealing with today, the leaders of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights have been released. It seems that they have always been dealt with in accordance with Egyptian law. I therefore ask myself the more general question of what the hostility towards Egypt in this Parliament is based on. Is Egypt being much stricter than other countries, or is there a fundamental rejection of the Egyptian state? Egypt opposes extremism that threatens us all – an extremism that threatens the Coptic community in Egypt. While Turkey continues to cause instability in the Middle East and beyond, Egypt is one of the few steadfast states that actually opposes Turkey's push for expansion. Egypt plays a crucial role in Libya, and it is Egyptian forces fighting the Syrian militias smuggled in by Turkey. Egypt, in particular, has inflicted deep wounds on Islamist extremism, which sows death and destruction worldwide. The Muslim Brotherhood has almost brought Egypt to its knees. The Egyptian state is resisting all these threats, while at the same time advancing progress in the fields of economy and education for its citizens, and it is forming alliances with like-minded countries in order to achieve a little more stability throughout the region. However, we are having endless discussions here in order to be able to criticise Egypt. A trial is not enough for us. We encourage opposition to the Egyptian Government, a government that is acting in our interests, in the interests of our security. And this unbroken criticism is straining our relations with Cairo, and that is certainly not in our interest. That is why we must think realistically and pragmatically. Egypt faces serious threats to its security from extremism, both internally and externally. That is why it is important for all of us to be constructively critical of Egypt, even with different opinions, rather than constantly rejecting it.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, dear colleagues, today, exactly 10 years ago, Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire starting what has long been called the Arab Spring, but was actually smashed with violence in so many places including in Egypt. In Egypt that is today run by a dictator – Mr Berg – a dictator that brands human rights’ defenders as terrorists, who puts people in jail for years for having not more than Whatsapp on their phones. And this dictator was received by President Emmanuel Macron last week who then officially announced that he will continue to supply this dictator with arms irrespective of his human rights record.  Dear colleagues, that is carte blanche for Macron to do even worse and it is a slap in the face of each and every one who has been fighting for freedom and democracy in the Middle East for the last 10 years, because we all know the arms of France, the arms of Germany and of so many other countries, have been used against the protesters. I don’t want us to go down this road. That is why we need a real arms embargo. We need to suspend any budget support to this regime, and we need to see all the political prisoners freed.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression and the right to a fair trial, must always be respected. I would like to express my concerns over the arrest and targeting of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR) and, generally, over the systemic targeting of human rights defenders by the Egyptian authorities. As many of my colleagues have done, I call for the release of all EIPR staff.  However, I would also like to note that Egypt remains an important partner for the EU in many areas. Unfortunately, the joint motion for a resolution neither recognises this, nor considers the severe terrorist threat from radical Islamist organisations that the authorities are trying to tackle. Additionally, the joint motion calls for sanctions that are too harsh, imposing monitoring measures coordinated by the EU, as well as for a complete review of all our existing relations. Thus I believe it goes beyond its original purpose. Therefore, my group won’t be able to vote in favour of the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Berg of the AfD: No, the regime in Egypt is by no means my interests, because I stand by human rights and the human rights situation in Egypt is worrying. Let me therefore say straightaway: cooperation with the coup leader al-Sisi is a betrayal of those who, as a result of the social uprisings, have demonstrated for months for democratic and social fundamental rights and freedoms. Al-Sisi is a representative of the Egyptian oligarchy who has managed to suppress the social and democratic popular movement over the justified outrage of the Muslim Brotherhood.  It is cynical that President Macron should put these human rights violations into perspective and continue to sell arms to the european Union regime. It is hypocritical that Egypt is also an EU partner in the defence of refugees. No, basic human rights are by no means a matter of disagreement. This is not only cynical, but also a typically brazen act of legitimising imperial interests.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 'I saw Regeni in office 13 and there were also two officers and other officers. When I walked into the office, I noticed iron chains that people were tying up with. He was half naked at the top, carrying signs of torture and babbling in his tongue, deliting. He was lying on the ground, his face back. I saw him handcuffed in handcuffs forcing him to the ground." These, according to the main eyewitness, were the last frames of the barbarically broken life of Giulio Regeni, an Italian citizen and European citizen. These are the treatment of thousands of activists every day, in a country where 3 000 people have been sentenced to death in recent years, more than 60 000 arrested and imprisoned on the basis of inconsistent evidence and mass trials, including Patrick Zaki and EIPR operators.  How long do you want to remain silent, while a country with which we have political and commercial ties turns into a regime of terror? Our credibility is at stake. Al-Sisi must respect our principles, not show our medals. We have a sanctions regime to trigger in the event of severe human rights violations. We cannot allow double standards. If not now when? Truth and justice for Giulio Regeni!

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, Europe certainly cannot tolerate retaliation against those who hold legitimate meetings with European diplomats or those who fight for the defence of human rights or make use of freedom of expression precisely now — as Mrs Neumann has said - when ten years of the Arab springs are served, which were precisely a demand for freedom and democracy.  I would like to express my solidarity with Patrick Zaki and his family, and to join my voice in calling on this Parliament to demand — and you have to do so together with the Commission and the high representative — your immediate release, Commissioner. It is inconceivable that an Erasmus Mundus student will be imprisoned and tortured for his research work.  But let's see, we heard the lords of the far right congratulate Al-Sisi, they are delighted with Al-Sisi because he is fighting Islamic terrorism. And I would say to you: gentlemen of the far right, you have us used to saying many barbarities, but really, what does Mr Patrick Zaki have to do with the fight against Islamic terrorism? What does Gulio Regeni, who was killed by Mr. Al-Sisi's security forces, have to do with the fight against Islamic terrorism? How can they say these things? How can the President of the French Republic, who we consider a European leader and therefore defender of the Enlightenment and human rights, give the Grand Cross of the Order of the Legion of Honour to The Dictator Al-Sisi?

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, civil liberties are under systemic government crackdown in Egypt. The senior members of a highly respected human rights group, Karim Ennarah, Mohammed Basheer and Gasser Abdel—Razek, were arbitrarily detained and continue to be harassed by the authorities. Patrick Zaki is an Erasmus student, a participant in our very own flagship programme. He was tortured and continues to be in police detention. Giulio Regeni was an Italian journalist, tortured and murdered, and justice has not been served until this day. And there are so many more cases. We are way past the point of deep concerns. We have just rolled out the EU Magnitsky Act. It’s time for High Representative Borrell to finally put targeted sanctions on the table.  Let’s review our EU aid programmes to make sure that no human rights abuser is propped up with EU taxpayers’ money but that we support civil society directly.  Finally, every time we sit down to talk to Egypt over any issue, these people’s stories and their human rights belong right there at the negotiating table.

name: Dominik TARCZYŃSKI
text: – Madam President, what a festival of hypocrisy from all of those coming from the left, from the liberals! You support Mr Macron and then you are the first to shout out that he’s selling arms to the Egyptian regime. So why do you support leftist ideology? Why do you support Mr Macron, who calls himself a liberal? Where are you liberals? First, you create a problem, and then you try to solve it.  First of all, when discussing human rights in Egypt, the main problem is the rights of the Christians – when people are killed, when priests are hanged and beheaded. This is what is happening now in Paris. This is what is happening now in Egypt. So, first you create a problem, then you’re the first to shout about wanting to solve that problem.  The main group facing prosecution is the Christians. So, I’m shouting in the name of the Christians in Egypt. Protect us! Protect us! Do not sell arms, or fight it with the political tools. Christianity and the Christmas season come from Christ, so Merry Christmas not ‘happy season’. Happy Christmas to you all.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: – Madam President, we are told by colleagues on the far right that dictator Al-Sisi should be congratulated because what he is practicing is the fight against terrorism.  We cannot accept, we cannot allow crimes to be camouflaged as a heroic struggle, that this is being used as a smokescreen to cover up mass arrests, torture and murders.  Gentlemen, what did Giulio Regeni have to do with terrorism? And he was arrested and tortured, and his body appeared in a ditch six days later, with a brain haemorrhage, because they went through torture.  What does the LGTBI people's rights activist have to do with terrorism?  And he's been detained and tortured since February.  What does Mrs Mahienur al-Masri, a human rights lawyer, have to do with terrorism? And she's been arrested three times in the last two years for which Mr. Macron gives the Legion of Honor medal. Less hypocrisy, gentlemen, you have to break ties with those... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: Mr President, "I am not going to make matters of defence and economic cooperation dependent on these differences." That was the answer of Macron, little Napoleon in the Elysée Palace to questions about the sale of arms to Egypt. Macron sells weapons to a dictator who would not hesitate to use them against his own people. Meanwhile, the European Parliament is concerned about the leaders' strapats in Hungary and Poland, which is small beer compared to Macron's undermining actions.  A deplorable economic situation in France forces little Napoleon to his knees. Forced by mounting debts, he is wasting our European values. What hope can egypt's political prisoners still have if Macron sells arms to al-Sisi? What hope can Nasrin, the Iranian human rights activist who has been imprisoned for years when she learns of Macron's corrupt stance? The economic situation caused by the COVID-19 pandemic is worrying. But the hypocrisy and cynicism of European political leaders is disastrous.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, I will of course vote for this resolution, with its share of warnings, protests and condemnations. I do so, like most of my colleagues, with conviction, compassion and solidarity with the victims of the abuses that have just been mentioned.  Unfortunately, too often, the political authorities responsible for the arbitrariness and suffering inflicted on their victims feel safe from punishment because there are the imperatives of Realpolitik. And then there are many partners who allow the same practices at home. I see Mrs. Arena nodding, which reinforces my point.  The free world is still too divided because everyone follows, most of the time, their own interests. That is why I will end with a note of optimism: the world summit on democracy announced by Joe Biden should be an opportunity to pave the way for a better structuring of the response of the free world to the leaders responsible for all these abuses.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we pay close attention to human rights developments in Egypt and address them in various ways. Arrests and prosecution of civil society organisations, and people expressing themselves on social media remain a cause for concern. In September 2020 at the 45th United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva, the EU raised various human rights issues in Egypt, under item 4, including a call to release human rights defenders. The recent arrests of the director and staff members of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights, the EIPR, underlined once more the worrying situation in this regard. We consider that the EIPR provides a critical service to the Egyptian people. We expressed our concern in a statement by the spokesperson of the European External Action Service on 21 November. We welcome as a first step, the release of the three EIPR staff members on 3 December, while reiterating our call for the release of Mr George Patrick Zaki, an EIPR researcher who has remained in detention since February 2020. We have also noted that the challenges mentioned take place against positive developments in social and economic rights, such as the protection of women amid the COVID pandemic, as highlighted in the latest UNDP UN Women report that shows Egypt is the best performer in the region. Further, on 25 November the Egyptian Government approved the implementing regulations of the 2019 NGO Law, which is an improvement from previous legislation and gives more predictability to charity organisations. The protection and promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law are guiding principles of our external action and policies. The new action plan on human rights and democracy 2020—2024, approved in November, reaffirms the EU’s strong commitment to further advancing universal values for all. These commitments also have a central place in the framework of our political engagement and cooperation with Egypt. This was also discussed during High Representative Borrell’s latest visit to Cairo on 3 September of this year, as well as that of the President of the European Council, Mr Michel, in November. The EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Gilmore, is also in regular contact with the relevant Egyptian counterparts. The EU has a clear interest in Egypt’s long—term stability and security. This can only be achieved if human rights are fully implemented and upheld. This remains the guiding torch in our bilateral dialogue with Egypt within the framework of our partnership.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, while the final vote will take place on Friday, 18 December 2020. Written observations (Article 171)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. It is appalling that some in France were outraged by Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's visit to Paris, since he was elected following the overthrow of his predecessor Mohamed Morsi, who is close to the Muslim Brotherhood. In addition, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has made a significant contribution to improving the condition of Egyptian Copts. This is evidenced by the inauguration in January 2019 of an impressive Nativity Cathedral in Egypt's new administrative capital, or the sharp increase in the number of Coptic candidates in the 2020 parliamentary elections.  These strong symbols of ecumenism cannot be ignored, at a time when, in the Near and Middle East, and even in sub-Saharan Africa, Christian communities seem to be gradually being wiped off the map. So much so that, in a report given to the former British Foreign Minister, the term "genocide" was no longer taboo. These acts must therefore be taken into account in the assessment of this regime, while the fight against Islamism occupies all minds.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on forced labour and the situation of the Uighurs in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (2020/2913(RSP)*. ___________

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: asks. Mr President! Right now there is a bestial repression of the Uyghur minority population in China. Forced labour, forced sterilisation and giant prison camps are unfortunately the everyday lives of hundreds of thousands of Uyghurs and other Muslim minorities in China. We need targeted sanctions against those responsible for the repression of the Uyghurs in the Chinese regime. Until now, the European Union has unfortunately failed in its efforts to combat the massive forced labour to which the Uyghurs are subjected. The EUROPEAN Union has chosen to stand idly by, while multinationals make a big profit from oppression. It has to stop. We need transparent value chains so that companies are held accountable when they make profits from oppression. The multinationals must feel that we do not accept that money is being made from the oppression of the Uyghurs and the Muslim minorities in China.  Ladies and gentlemen! That requires us to act now. This requires the EU to step up its efforts. It calls for targeted sanctions against those responsible in the Chinese regime, and it requires us to take decisive action against the multinationals that profit from the repression.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The resolution on the situation in Xinjiang, which we are debating today, shows the great agreement of the democratic groups, and that is a good thing. Where human rights are trampled underfoot, we show solidarity together. However, I think it is scandalous that some radical left Members of this House have tabled motions on behalf of the GUE Group in which they show solidarity with the authoritarian Communist Party propaganda from Beijing instead of the victims of human rights violations. The GUE should consider where it actually stands. We do not just want to criticise verbally the crimes against humanity in Xinjiang committed there against the Uighurs. We also want action to follow. These demands go primarily to politics and the economy. To be clear, there must be sanctions against those responsible in Xinjiang and against companies like XPCC that exploit forced laborers. Europe's firms, which cannot ensure that they become collaborators of the oppressive regime, who cannot prevent them from becoming collaborators, should leave Xinjiang.  Products from Uighur forced labour must not enter the EU market. In the investment agreement with China, the EU must insist that the International Labour Organisation (ILO) anti-forced labour conventions be ratified. I cannot imagine this House agreeing if there are no clear commitments to this in the investment agreement.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Author. Mr President, the Chinese state has been mercilessly oppressing Uighurs and other Muslim minorities in Xinjiang for years, and a number of European companies have been complicit. The horrors of the Chinese state are almost incomprehensible. Of the 10 million Uighurs in Xinjiang, more than one million are in gruesome internment camps. 900 000 children have been taken away from their parents and put in state orphanages, and uighurs are systematically imprisoned, tortured, surveilled and forced into abortion and sterilisation.  Let's call this what it is. The Chinese state is committing a crime against humanity and this week an additional figure was added. More than half a million: that is the number of Uighurs forcing the Chinese state into forced labour, to pick the cotton from which our clothing is made, including by European companies. What we are talking about here is modern slavery and any involvement in forced labour is absolutely unacceptable. It is unpalatable that European companies are involved. This cannot be without consequences.  A new EU sanctions regime has recently been adopted to deal swiftly and harshly with the most serious human rights abusers. Now that list is empty. I call for the Chinese officials and state-owned enterprises responsible for this forced labour, mass incarceration and oppression to be the first to add to this. China has yet to end this criminal campaign today. Let me be very clear: in our European shops there is no place for products to which the taint of Uighur forced labour is attached.
