Any product that violates human rights in the supply chain should therefore be banned.  In Europe, Uighurs, Hong Kongers, Tibetans and dissidents are safe. In China, their lives are in danger. We will never condone China's brutal campaign of oppression, forced labour and religious persecution. There's no excuse anymore. Act now, the Uighurs need us.

name: Assita KANKO
text: author. – Madam President, can you imagine what it must be like to be forced to be sterilised, to be forced to undergo abortion, to be tortured, to be used as a slave, to have your children taken away from you? Because that is the reality for so many Uyghurs and other Muslim minorities in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Twenty percent of the world’s cotton production originates from Xinjiang, often harvested with the use of forced labour. The supply chain for textile products, including masks sold in our pharmacies here in Europe, are part of an economy that is based on forced labour and a lot of exploitation and suffering. Our companies cannot simply turn a blind eye and claim ignorance. They have a duty to better monitor their supply chains. China is not simply an economic partner; it is a country edging towards the definition of carrying out genocide. The EU and Member States must put in place effective controls and place an import ban on Chinese products made using forced labour. The EU should enforce targeted sanctions against Chinese officials responsible for overseeing these shocking crimes. It’s time to stop talking and practice what we actually believe.

name: Engin EROGLU
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there are many spectators at home on the screens. The dam of silence and false truths is now cracking. Every day, men, women and children are violently broken with the sole aim of giving up their own identity, their own lives. What is taking place in Xinjiang is a systematic nightmare of mass incarceration, human rights violations and the mass sterilization of Uighur women. We know from a report by Adrian Zenz that more than 500 000 people in Xinjiang have to work in the cotton industry. Production accounts for 20% of the world's cotton production. We, we in the European Parliament today, document the greatest enslavement and violation of human rights in the world at the moment. We, here in the European Parliament, are closing ranks today. For far too long, decision-makers have remained silent. I would like to apologise personally for that.  Today's resolution on the fate of the Uighurs is finally becoming a practice out of rhetoric. We have targeted sanctions against those responsible under the EU's Magnitsky Act. "Protection of Uighurs in the EU and in third countries" is stated in the resolution. We no longer want a summit between the European Union and China, at which human rights are not also discussed. At the end of the day, we call on the United Nations to conduct an independent fact-finding mission in China. But that is not the end of the road. In Tibet, Mongolia and Hong Kong, too, people have significant problems with the Chinese government and are fighting for freedom. We must look for partners such as Taiwan, who are also standing up for freedom under Chinese pressure.

name: Miriam LEXMANN
text: author. – Madam President, let me begin by thanking my colleagues and all the staff for the excellent cooperation in drafting the urgency resolution. Its strong message is a testimony to the cross-party commitment to stand with the Uyghurs and all those whose human dignity and freedoms are being violated every day. Just in the recent years, the Chinese Communist Party has built an Orwellian state that has introduced mass surveillance, engaged in forced organ-harvesting from prisoners of conscience, forced sterilisation, forced labour, and has placed over one million Uyghurs in the concentration camps. It systematically destroyed thousands of churches, mosques and other places of worship and culture. It behaves with increasingly brute force across mainland China and Hong Kong, and threatens and bullies Taiwan and countries around the globe. Moreover, Cardinal Bo said rightly that ‘it is the oppression, the lies and corruption of the CCP that are responsible’ for the current pandemics. Dear colleagues, it is the right time to re-think our relationship with China, ensuring a value-based and consistent approach towards the Chinese Communist Party. We must understand that our values do not hinder our policies – but policies that ignore our values do. If the EU wants to have credibility as a global actor, it must ensure a consistent value-based foreign policy. That must mean seeing the Chinese Communist Party for what it is, while engaging positively with the Chinese people. That must mean standing with the Uyghurs, Hongkongers, Tibetans, and all those oppressed by the Chinese Communist Party. That must mean clear consequences for the suppression of human dignity and freedoms, such as imposing targeted sanctions. That must mean upholding corporate responsibility through due diligence in our supply chains and banning the import of all products made by forced labour. That must mean working closely with our democratic allies in addressing human rights violations across mainland China and Hong Kong, and coordinating our policies on sanctions, import bans and other measures to send a clear message: we will defend human dignity. We will defend freedom.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, recently I saw documentaries on RTE and the BBC highlighting that the Chinese Government has reportedly detained more than a million Muslims in re-education camps. The Presidency has amassed power, using more and more unapologetic means to suffocate internal dissent or desire for political reform. And like many in this House, I am deeply concerned about the increasingly suppressive regime in China and how many religious and ethnic minorities, in particular the Uyghurs and Kazakhs, face a violation of their human dignity, as well as a denial of their rights to freedom of speech, cultural expression and religious belief, as well as peaceful assembly. Chinese officials maintain that what they call ‘vocational training centres’ do not infringe on Uyghurs’ rights. They have refused to share information about their detention centres. Nevertheless, internal Chinese Government documents leaked in late 2019 have provided important details of how officials launched and maintained the detention camps, as do the RTE and BBC documentaries and satellite imagery. The Chinese authorities need to immediately, and unconditionally, release the Uyghur scholar and Sakharov Prize winner in 2019, Ilham Tohti. The global influence of China is clearly growing. It is because China is so economically influential that democracies who respect the rule of law and fundamental human rights need to coordinate more effectively in implementing sanctions and other measures to address human rights violations in mainland China and its other regions. Nothing else will suffice.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, this resolution on forced labour by the Uighurs in China is coming more than in time. Earlier this week, the Centre for Global Policy published a study showing that the problem is much bigger than we initially thought, and that therefore a lot of the cotton on our market has been picked by forced labour in China. It must be clear that international companies, but also European companies, are actually closing their eyes and not looking at what their subcontractors are doing. So the Commission's proposal on due diligence – as has been said many times here – must come very quickly. We have to work on it very quickly. But we must also take responsibility through trade policy. We are currently negotiating an investment deal. Let us ensure that there is a dd chapter on human rights and forced labour and that it is enforceable. Trade policy does not stand alone, but must be one of our powerful tools for changing the world for the better. Let us do the same by ensuring that we use our economic weight to eliminate forced labour.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, 're-education camps', say Chinese leaders. Oh, yes? But what is forced labour re-educating more than a million Uighurs locked up in these concentration camps? Well, it is to bow to a single party that demands and would like to impose the assimilation of minorities to the majority ethnic group that are re-educated the Uighurs as, for that matter, the Tibetans and the Mongols. One people for one party is the objective of these ethnocides that take place before our eyes, without anyone being able to ignore them. We know, everyone knows, but the Chinese regime dares to present its dictatorship as preferable to democracies. Everyone knows, but the governments of Muslim countries are silent, while Islamist movements, so quick to denounce Islamophobia everywhere else, say nothing. Not a word. So Mr Xi, we are telling you from this Parliament, Europe is telling you: this crime, you are personally responsible for it and we hold you personally guilty.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID group. - What did General de Gaulle say in 1964 when he recognized the Republic of China? Two things. He felt that China should be recognized, because the weight of evidence and reason weighed more and more every day. And he added: "It is not out of the question that China will become, in the next century, what it was for centuries, the greatest power of the universe."  Here we are. The emergence of a multipolar world greatly weakens American domination over the world, and every piece of information about China must be the subject of our critical thinking. Like you, I call for a China that respects religious freedom and actively participates in the concert of nations. This is what we must work on effectively, not the proliferation of declarations of distrust of Beijing. This is in Europe's interest and it is in the interest of all of our countries. Exactly one year ago, we were voting on resolutions on Hong Kong. What were they used for? What have they changed? If we want to engage in a real dialogue with Beijing rather than a policy of permanent denunciation, then perhaps we can make a difference.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, 20% of the world's cotton is now produced in Xinjiang Province, where, as we have known for several years, all kinds of human rights violations take place in great indifference: forced labour, rape, torture, mass surveillance, forced sterilization, confinement in re-education camps, harassment of the Muslim minority and intimidation of the press and activists. We can no longer turn a blind eye to what amounts to crimes against humanity, as today's resolution makes clear. When our children call us, we will not be able to say that we did not know. I thank and congratulate Antoine Griezmann for his courage and responsibility to cancel his collaboration with Huawei, accused of participating in the surveillance of the Uighurs. Let us take our European champion as an example, because we all have a responsibility and a role to play. I therefore call on all companies, especially In Europe, to cease all trade with goods produced in Xinjiang. History will judge us. If we fail to stop these human rights violations, history will judge us.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, it cannot be the case that we simply continue to trade with impunity with a country that has forced more than a million people to be locked up in penal camps, sterilises women on a large scale, forced mass workers to work on cotton plantations and factories – under the guise of poverty alleviation – and systematically observes its Uighur nationals systematically , infiltrates and intimidates, up to the EU Member States? Not to mention the increasing pressure on Christian and other religious communities in the rest of China, or the increasing repression in Hong Kong.  This can't go on. The time for just talking is over. Recent human rights dialogues have made no progress. China is increasingly transforming from a strategic partner into a systematic rival. The recently adopted Magnitsky sanctions instrument must therefore be used as soon as possible against accomplices in this matter. The EU should no longer conclude economic agreements without firm concessions from the Chinese side on human rights. It's time to put the deed to the floor.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, it is worrying that the European Union and its institutions, as this debate and resolution in this Parliament demonstrate, become a sounding board of the confrontation strategy promoted by the US Administration of The United States against the People's Republic of China.  The European Parliament not only joins in but is promoting an unacceptable disinformation operation that seeks to cover the campaign against China after the failed attempt by the United States of America to create a focus of destabilization in the autonomous Uighur region of Xinjiang. The claim to human rights by those who, like the European Union, so often affront them, is, in fact, an exercise in hypocrisy which it uses in an attempt to stop and, if possible, prevent china's rapid economic and technological development.  We are voting against this resolution, which is part of a policy of confrontation, interference and aggression against the People's Republic of China and its people.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, no one can deny the evidence that China is committing serious massive human rights violations against the Uyghur people. We cannot continue to do nothing and accept a shameful situation committed by a country with which we have strong relations and exchanges. In this regard, the Uyghur World Congress urged the EU to take action to combat this crime and suggested several measures: sanctions for those mainly responsible for these violations (we know who they are); a cotton import ban from Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region; ensuring that companies do not benefit from forced labour; making all EU China investment agreements conditional on concrete advance on the respect for human rights; organising an independent fact-finding mission to Xinjiang; ensuring free and unrestricted access to the internment camps for any potential visit; and, of course, organising a visit to the political prisoner Ilham Tohti, 2019 Sakharov Prize winner, unjustly imprisoned in China.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Madam President, we call them 'detention centres', the Chinese authorities call them 'political re-education centres'. In the Xinjiang Autonomous Region, these internment camps are expanding. Reports considered credible estimate that more than one million Uighurs are detained. In addition, surveys indicate that Uighurs are forced to work in clothing or technology production lines. In March 2020, the Australian Strategic Policy Institute denounced the fact that these plants supply a large number of brands, including European multinationals. That same month, I asked the Commission whether it could provide information on this forced labour and on the companies involved, whether products could be identified and, above all, whether some were exported to the European Union. Finally, I asked whether the Commission was considering measures if it turned out that such products had entered the European market. In his reply, the High Representative expressed concern. He said he had raised his concerns with the Chinese authorities - allegations rejected by the authorities - and wanted to continue to address the issue. Finally, he said he had urged China to allow observers in Xinjiang. You will understand my disappointment when you read the answer. However, if the recent reports on our national channels and other media do not lie, the question is no longer whether the European market is concerned, but what the Commission will do to react to products related to forced labour in our markets. For it seems undeniable that many of the masks made in China that we wear were made as part of forced labour, that the harvesting of cotton used in many garments for sale in Europe was made with forced labour. So, again, what measures will the Commission take while waiting for a proposal for legislation on the duty of vigilance? Answers are an urgent request from the European Parliament.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, I accuse. I accuse the leaders of the Chinese Communist Party of the worst crime against humanity in the 21st century: the deportation and eradication of the Uighur people.  I'm blaming you. I accuse the international community of consenting to this crime by its silence and passivity. I'm blaming you. I accuse the leaders of many Muslim countries, from Pakistan to Saudi Arabia, who on the one hand brandish their faith as a standard and on the other support the Chinese policy of destroying mosques and desecration of cemeteries.  I'm blaming you. I blame the greedy bosses of Nike, Zara and so many other multinationals who benefit from the enslavement of a people. Finally, I accuse the European leaders of cowardice and lust. These leaders, we urged them a year ago to take action to close these camps. What have they done in the last year? Nothing. Nothing at all. A footballer like Griezmann or thousands of young people on social media have done more in a year for the Uighurs than all our leaders put together.  So let me be clear: if these leaders sit down on the resolution we are voting on today, if they refuse to punish the Chinese leadership, history will find them complicit in crimes against humanity and we will try them before it.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – A Uachtaráin, go raibh maith agaibh as an deis a thabhairt dom labhairt ar an gceist thábhachtach seo.  Is scannal agus smál ar an daonnacht atá i bpáirt againn is na milliúin de na hUigiúraigh a bheith faoi ghlas i gCampaí Géibhinn sa tSín. Is léir chomh maith go bhfuil eagla rómhór roimh an tSín ar fhormhór mhuintir an domhain aon rud a dhéanamh faoi sin. Maidir le comhshamhlú éigeantach na nUigiúrach i gcultúr Han na Síne, is rud is sin a bhaineann leis an am atá caite agus ní leis an mbliain 2020. An t-ábhar imní is mó atá ann, áfach, ná teip an phobail idirnáisiúnta an fód a sheasamh in aghaidh na Síne faoi sin, agus go deimhin, faoi go leor ábhar eile nach iad.  Más féidir leis an réimeas Síneach a rialaíonn an tSín, agus is d'aon ghnó a úsáidim an focal réimeas, neamhshuim a dhéanamh den chuid eile den domhan, cén dóchas atá ag mionlaigh eitneacha amhail Críostaithe agus Búdaithe na Tide sa tír sin? Ní mór don Aontas Eorpach a chumhacht eacnamaíoch agus airgeadais a úsáid chun brú a chur ar an tSín. B'fhéidir go bhfuil gá le smachtbhannaí trádála. Nílim cinnte cad ba cheart a dhéanamh, ach is eol dom go bhfuil an méid atá ag tarlú do na hUigiúraigh mícheart air bhonn morálta agus go bhfuil sé de dhualgas orainn gníomhú ina leith sin.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, China has upgraded its instruments for genocide to the 21st century, using biometric and surveillance technology for the ethnic cleansing of millions of Uyghurs at the speed and precision of a computer. The Chinese Communist Party acts through machines and thinks like machines. In factories, it exploits minorities to the death, under the motto of washing brains, cleaning hearts, upholding the law, removing what is wrong. Ladies and gentlemen, DNA recording, facial scanning, fingerprint and voice recording, sterilisation, brainwashing – and worse – of 82 global companies involved in the general silence, many are European. 20 % of the world's cotton comes from forced labour by Uyghurs. The United States has sanctioned 24 Chinese companies specializing in artificial intelligence and facial control, and what have we done instead?

name: Yannick JADOT
text: (start of off-mic intervention) ... crimes against humanity, cultural genocide, concentration camps, forced sterilization, forced labour in many economic sectors, including cotton. So, yes, the International Criminal Court. Yes, sanctions against the Chinese leaders involved. Of course, the embargo against all companies and products from Xinjiang. But a few hundred yards from the European Parliament in Brussels, we are currently negotiating an investment agreement with China, as if all this dramatic reality, as if all the values of the European Union weighed nothing in relation to business, in relation to Chinese investments in our economy as well as European investments in China. In the name of the values of Europe, in the name of the fight against these genocides, in the name of the values of democracy, in the name of fundamental freedoms, I call on European leaders, I call on Emmanuel Macron for France, to suspend all negotiations with China as long as absolute violence, as long as repression, as long as the camps continue in Xinjiang as in other regions where minorities are mistreated , repressed, tortured. So, Emmanuel Macron like all European leaders, stop the massacre, stop the negotiations with China until the fundamental freedoms go well.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, Human Rights and China are like the Croatian judiciary and justice.  In China, ethnic, political and religious minorities are systematically persecuted. Aside from forced labor, incarceration in concentration camps, torture, perhaps the worst is forced organ harvesting, sometimes alive. One of the groups, i.e. minorities, most exposed to forced organ extraction is Falun Dafa or Falun Gong because they are usually very healthy people, both mentally and physically. And persecution has persisted since 1999 when they fell out of the merciless communist party of China. Why is it done? To eliminate the political enemy, to make money on trade and to support China's health care system. Records show that two-thirds of all transplant tourists go to China to get an organ. Organs are waiting in China for weeks or even days while in Europe it is about age. It turns out that the Communist Party of China not only knows about this, but that it benefits directly from it all. There is even a list of European institutions and American or companies that are related to this and make money off of this. And all this will continue because Europe is unfortunately afraid of China's economic power.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, does anyone in this room, I am sure, that among the components of your clothing is no cotton produced by the forced labour of Uighur prisoners in the cynically named "re-education camps" of Xinjiang? What's it feel like? Discomfort. For, there is only one way to put an end to this, to adopt and implement the due diligence mechanism in order to remove products from our supply chains from human rights violations.  The brutal repression in Xinjiang against the Uighur and Kazakh populations is outrageous and cannot go unpunished. The global regime of sanctions against human rights violations should be applied to the Chinese authorities involved in ethnic, religious and political persecution in Xinjiang, but also in Tibet.  Yesterday was Sakharov Prize day, today is the day to remember that Islam Toti remains detained without contact with his family and without his lawyer, but I also can not fail to recall the case of Tsz Lun Kok, citizen of Hong Kong, with dual Portuguese nationality, ie, European citizen, detained since August incommunicado in China.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Madam President, the Chinese Government is forcing hundreds of thousands of Uyghurs from Xinjiang to do forced labour. Chinese officials go door to door and select people for the cotton harvest. At least 570 000 people have had to undergo forced training before being sent into the cotton fields hundreds of miles away from home. Eighty-five percent of all Chinese cotton comes from Xinjiang, and this is a fifth of the world’s cotton supply. A majority of Chinese cotton ends up on the Asian market, where many clothes are made that are sold right here in the European Union. And that’s not all: new investigations confirm that medical masks and protective equipment made by Uyghurs are sold in the EU. This is unacceptable, just like the detention camps in which more than a million Uyghurs are detained. We must be able to make companies aware of their responsibility, and they must intervene when their production chain is not transparent. I urge the Commission to speed up the introduction of due diligence legislation.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Of course, I condemn forced labour and I condemn child labour. There is no doubt that the Uighur minority is subject to discrimination by the Chinese Government. And, in my view, it is clear that the Chinese authorities are guilty of serious human rights violations. I am not advocating ignoring forced labour or other forms of discrimination against Uighurs. Greater transparency on the part of the Chinese government about the internal threats facing the country, an immediate shift away from forced and child labour and re-education camps, and a differentiation between the predominantly peaceful members of the Uighur minority and those few who have joined extremism could help bring more stability to the region.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has In China, Uighurs, Muslim minorities and Tibetans are dramatically oppressed, and that is well known. Hundreds of thousands of Uighurs are forcibly used in cotton harvesting, and this cotton also ends up on the counters in Europe. The EU and national governments must clearly identify these human rights violations, and companies that produce in China must review and realign their supply chains – they cannot avoid doing so. Apple, Nike, Adidas, Samsung, VW and BMW – these names must stand for responsibility. We in Europe are opposed to Huawei designing facial recognition software that recognises the ethnicity of minorities. We do not want to do business in Europe with companies that actively support regimes that commit massive human rights violations. This is not just a security issue. The EU is now negotiating with China on fair competition opportunities and better market access in the Investment Protection Agreement. We now expect the German EU Presidency to spell this out clearly. We do not want products from Chinese forced labour in Europe. China must ratify the core ILO core standards, and human rights are non-negotiable! No other city in Europe has as many Uighurs as Munich – where I come from. Dear Mehriban, we cannot care about the fate and well-being of the Uighurs in Europe!

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union has spoken out clearly and repeatedly on the situation of Uyghurs, expressing grave concerns about political re-education camps, surveillance and restrictions on freedom of religion and belief. As HR/VP Borrell mentioned during the debate on the situation of the Uyghurs one year ago, the policies applied to Xinjiang appear disproportionate to the stated aim of fighting against terrorism and extremism. The conclusions of United Nations experts expressing serious concerns are, regretfully, still valid. During the past year, a number of reports have brought to light worrying allegations that Uyghurs and other minorities in China are subject to forced labour and forced labour transfer schemes, as well as forced sterilisation and forced birth control. They add to the gravity and magnitude of concerns we have already expressed. EU leaders raised these concerns in their meetings with Chinese leaders this year, at the EU-China Summit on 22 June and at the EU-China leaders’ meeting on 14 September. We also issued a comprehensive statement during the last UN Human Rights Council under item 4: debate on human rights situations that require the Council’s attention. We clearly highlighted the need for meaningful access to the region for independent experts. We will continue to call on China to uphold its national and international obligations and to respect human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, especially in Xinjiang and Tibet. Defending human rights and combating forced labour are priorities for the EU. As a key trading partner of the EU, China should ensure that business activities in its territory meet international standards on labour rights and responsible business conduct. We expect the Chinese authorities to implement those standards across all sectors of production and at all levels of supply chains. Responsible business practices by European companies working in China play a very important role. While the Commission is working on a legislative proposal on sustainable corporate governance, the EU already has mandatory standards in some sectors and actively promotes international guidelines. European companies are already encouraged to implement effective due diligence practices across their supply chains. The Commission and the European External Action Service will continue working with companies to underscore the importance of taking up international due diligence guidelines in all aspects, including human rights. The new EU global human rights sanctions regime, adopted on 7 December, enables the EU to forcefully stand up for human rights. It allows the EU to target human rights violations and abuses worldwide, irrespective of where they occur. The regime does not contain any listings yet. However, we expect discussions on listings to start soon. I thank you all for your engagement in this debate and your contributions to further increase the awareness on this matter.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place today.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Iran, in particular the case of 2012 Sakharov Prize winner Nasrin Sotoudeh (2020/2914(RSP))*. _________________ * See minutes of the meeting.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Author. Madam President, the case of Nasrin Sotoudeh underlines the extreme precariousness of the status of women in so many countries around the world, where Sharia law is elevated to the status of law.  Indeed, the scandal of this lawyer sentenced to 38 years in prison, in particular for having shown herself without a hijab, is not specific to Iran. The trial this week in a special court against terrorism of Saudi feminist activist Loujain Al-Hathloul after two years of detention, according to his relatives, of ill-treatment and humiliation. However, the scandal did not prevent Saudi Arabia from hosting the G20 virtual summit last month, illustrating the Western powers' constant dual discourse on fundamental rights and women's issues.  If today's debate has only one merit, it is to recall that at a time when one is burdening with a bad trial in Islamophobia anyone who rejects certain practices of another age, the most basic freedoms of women are, alas, not everywhere obvious.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: asks. Madam President! Today we are sending a clear message from the European Parliament: stop the repression in Iran! The Iranian clerical regime is grossly oppressing the Iranian people and has sent thousands of political opponents to prison or death with executions. This is completely unacceptable. But we also send our solidarity to the courageous people of Iran who defy oppression in their struggle for democracy and justice. The brave Iranian women need our support when they defy the darkened mullahs in the fight for the right to control their own bodies. That is why we say: release Nasrin Sotoudeh, release the political prisoners, punish those responsible for the human rights violations against the Iranian people.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: author. – Madam President, Nasrin Sotoudeh is a human rights lawyer. This means that she uses the laws of her country, Iran, to defend her clients, the people of Iran, against a regime that does not feel bound by any of these laws. The more Nasrin uses these laws, the more absurd become the charges of that regime. The latest one: 33 years and 148 lashes for defending women that took off their hijabs.  Nasrin has now been 10 years in and out of prison in one of the countries with the cruellest prison conditions, amidst the raging COVID pandemic. Nasrin Sotoudeh really pays a high price for her love of the law and of the people of Iran. I’m full of admiration for this unbreakable woman and I think she rightfully deserved the Sakharov Prize from this Parliament.  As you all know, Nasrin is not the only one. The regime’s repression got a lot crueller recently, with arrests and executions. Ruhollah Zam was executed last week, while Ahmadreza Djalali is threatened with execution, and no justice has been done for the thousands of protesters in the streets of Iran last year.  That is why I think it’s so important that we send two clear signals today. One signal to the regime that if they continue like this they will be even more isolated and subject to targeted sanctions. And one signal to the brave Iranians, the vibrant and diverse civil society. You have our full solidarity, our full attention, our full support, as long as this is needed. Because, just like Nasrin, I hope that one day all the prisons of Iran will be turned into museums and parks.  (Applause)

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his The human rights situation in Iran is very serious. Sakharov Prize winner Nasrin Sotoudeh – lawyer, human rights campaigner, child defender, women's defender, defender of journalists – this brave woman who for 15 years has dedicated her professional life to helping people get the punishment to be imprisoned. Now she, who has given voice to so many others, needs our voice. We need to show that we are on her side and that we are calling for immediate release. We also demand that Iran stop the attacks on Iranians with dual citizenship. We are currently seeing scientists, journalists, environmentalists imprisoned. One of those that we are very fond of and which we highlight in particular is Dr Ahmadreza Djalali. His family suffers, he suffers, he faces an presumed death sentence. We call for his release, and we want to see the Commission acting in support of his case.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: author. – Madam President, ever since I heard the horrible news that the execution of Djalali was a matter of hours or days away, I have thought: what more can I do? I wrote letters, I spoke to the ambassador, but nevertheless. Now we finally have this resolution, and it sends a strong message to Iran. We have the new Magnitsky Act and we will use it if Djalali is not freed. I’d like to convey a message from Djalali’s wife, with whom I spoke yesterday. She says: ‘Ahmadreza is nothing but an innocent scientist and father of two children. He worked to improve the lives of others through his research. If he is executed, nothing can bring him back. So please, put all your efforts in and make sure he’s freed before it’s too late.’ Colleagues, let us vote in favour of this strong resolution and make sure it’s not too late.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: author. – Madam President, the Swedish citizen Ahmadreza Djalali faces imminent execution in the Islamic Republic of Iran for refusing to spy on European institutions on behalf of the mullahs. On behalf of conservatives, I demanded sanctions against Iranian authorities. I thank the lead negotiator, MEP Lega, for his leadership. Swedes should note that a new conservative government in Sweden would bring hope for a less appeasing foreign policy. That shift is desperately needed. As my other Swedish colleague, MEP Guteland, exerted her and the Social Democrats’ influence to water down the text, MEP Guteland, I want you one day, as me, to clearly say that ‘I support the aspirations of the Iranian people who want to live in a free, stable, inclusive and democratic country.’ Please say it out loud. The Iranian people need it.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Author. Madam President, Nasrin Sotoudeh is back in prison. His crime? To have defended, as a lawyer, the rights of women, children, religious minorities, journalists, artists before the Iranian courts. The Iranian authorities sentenced her to 33 years in prison and 148 lashes for that reason. We, the European Parliament, awarded him the 2012 Sakharov Prize for his struggles. Nasrin is a particularly courageous woman who deserves our support, as she supported those who needed her. She did so at the cost of her freedom. We will continue to support her until the Iranian authorities release her. Nasrin Sotoudeh has always been committed to the death penalty not being imposed, so that it would not be implemented. Just five days ago, journalist Rouhollah Zam was executed by hanging. The decision of the Iranian Supreme Court had been taken only four days earlier, on the basis of dubious charges and forced confessions. Rouhollah Zam had been granted political asylum in France and was kidnapped on Iraqi territory to be brought to Iran. The execution of Rouhollah Zam is a flagrant violation of international law and human rights. There is also Ahmadreza Djalali, the Iranian-Swedish doctor who is a university professor in Brussels and Italy. He was charged with death threats against himself and his family in Sweden and Iran. Confessions were extorted under torture and he was sentenced to death. He's awaiting his imminent execution. We call for the urgent intervention of the European Union and member states with the Iranian authorities in order to free Ahmadreza Djalali. I have appointed three people, one imprisoned, one executed, another on death row. For these three and for many others named in our resolution, how many anonymous people, arrested by the Iranian authorities for expressing their thoughts, for defending freedom of thought, for refusing to submit, for simply protecting another person who did not want to enter the imposed mould? We condemn in the strongest terms human rights abuses in Iran, arbitrary detentions following peaceful demonstrations, detentions of journalists and human rights defenders. We ask that Iran respect the rights of prisoners, the right to a fair trial, the right to choose one's lawyer. We call for the implementation of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, a pact to which Iran is a party. We simply ask that Iran respect the human rights, the human dignity inherent in all human beings, equal for all men and women. The European Union must work to implement all the means at its disposal to convince and get the Iranian authorities to change their practices.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, in October the High Commissioner asked us to take a holistic approach to Iran. This was particularly so in relation to preserving the nuclear agreement, which I agree with, and the result, of course, was a triumph for European diplomacy. The other side of the coin is the human rights record in Iran, which is not pretty – particularly the case of the 2012 Sakharov Prize winner Nasrin Sotoudeh. We have a duty to follow all laureates of this prize and to speak out when they are being persecuted. We did this in the case of Nasrin in 2018, and it is deeply regrettable that we must return to renew our call on the Iranian authorities to release her from her arbitrary detention. Today we call for the unconditional release of Nasrin Sotoudeh with renewed urgency. The people of Iran are struggling to battle the COVID—19 pandemic; prisoners – not just in Iran but around the world – are at an increased risk of infection. Nasrin unfortunately contracted the virus recently while she was granted temporary release. She was ordered to return to prison again against the advice of medical experts. Shameful – because this has the potential to be a fatal decision. I’m also dismayed by the continuously high use of capital punishment in Iran. This is not acceptable under any circumstances. Certainly a journalist should not be executed for expressing their views, and laureates should not be tortured and imprisoned for peacefully working to preserve human rights. I call on Iran to call a halt to this practice immediately. While we focus on the case of Nasrin, we must also think of all the other peaceful campaigners and activists, some of whom worked with her and who are facing a similar plight in Iran. Tá súil agam go n-éireoidh linn Nasrin, agus daoine nach í, a shaoradh agus a thabhairt ar ais dá dteaghlach roimh Nollaig.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of The President, yesterday we presented the Sakharov Prize to the movement for democracy in Belarus. Nasrin Sotoudeh has been our Sakharov Prize since 2012 and, since 2012, Nasrin Sotoudeh has been in prison.  Nasrin Sotoudeh - I had taken a picture that I can't show you - she's a smiling woman, a strong woman. During the two weeks of respite granted to him by the Iranian Islamic Republic, we had the opportunity to have him in the DROI sub-committee of this Parliament. She is still a strong woman, a smiling woman, but she is a woman terribly weakened by COVID and the imprisonment she is undergoing.  Nasrin Sotoudeh, it has been said, defended women's rights, men's rights, the right to justice in this country. We demand that any dialogue with Iran be pre-requisened for the release of Nasrin Sotoudeh. I'm thinking about her husband and her children. Cheer up.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, this is a special year coming to an end. 2020 fades and everything has changed.  Everything has changed - or almost. In Tehran, it is business as usual: repressions and executions that follow inexorably. We were writing this resolution earlier this week about Nasrin Sotoudeh, our 2012 Sakharov Prize, when we learned on Monday of the sentence of a young woman to ten years in prison for posting on Instagram a controversial selfie with the features of Angelina Jolie.  Two days earlier, two notches higher in barbarism, the mullahs had Rouhollah Zam executed, in a hurry, after a mock trial. The reporter was guilty of telling the truth. The journalist was guilty of uncovering corruption. For Tehran, always business as usual and no reason to worry that this will have consequences on relations with the European Union. And yet, on the same day, the European Union cancelled a Europe-Iran economic forum.  That is what we need to do very clearly: withdraw our investments, sanction them economically, target those responsible. It is not too late to release Nasrin Sotoudeh. It is not too late either for Professor Ahmadreza Djalali, who is awaiting execution in prison. 2020 is fading, that has to change.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission, the text we are debating today is entirely shared by all. This is not the first time that we have drawn up and voted on resolutions against bloodthirsty regimes, against those who suppress the freedom of journalists, lawyers, men and women who are fighting for freedom.  And I ask myself and I ask you, let us reflect together on whether we would have had the courage of these men and women. I come from a family that fought fascism and I identify with those who fight and fought for freedom in the past. Today, the news is so rapid that we had already decided to work on the case of Nasrin Sotoudeh – which we obviously hope will soon be released – but we also have to deal with the case of Ruhollah Zam, the journalist who was killed, the case of Dr Djalali, who is awaiting a death sentence, which we hope will not happen. The case of Nasrin Sotoudeh is very similar to that of Nasibe Semsai, a woman arrested in Turkey a few weeks ago, or Fariba Adelkhah. Women and men who have a courage that we often lack too. So let us ask ourselves this too, not least so as not to render useless a debate and a resolution which I hope will be important and perhaps help us – we talked about it with the High Representative a few weeks ago – to understand what to do with this nuclear agreement, what to do with relations with the United States, which in my opinion will not change much in their opposition to the Iranian regime, because if the Western front is divided , we are in danger of not being effective in the fight against a regime that must be fought and possibly brought down.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, today we are going to demand here the freedom of the 2012 Sakharov Prize, the lawyer Nasrín Sotudé, imprisoned in her homeland, in Iran, but above all we will denounce the behavior of the regime that tortures the Iranians, invades the region, promotes terrorism, proclaims wanting to exterminate Jews, like Hitler, and threatens peace around the world with its nuclear program. And it penetrates and sabotages democracies in Latin America and here in Europe, in Spain, funding a government party, Podemos.  I also report here European condescension with this murderous regime. Last December, the regime murdered 1,500 young people on its streets asking for freedom. Two months later, Mr Borrell, in Tehran, gave his smiling hand to the dome of the executioners, in search of European business. And, in this House, I believe that most were in their day in favor of lifting the embargo and running back to Iran to do business, while Trump was insulted for keeping that criminal regime out.  Therefore, the opposite of what is done is the right thing to do. Let's go to a real regime fence, to a firm front with the United States, so Iran knows it has to stop doing what it does.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, these urgencies are the epitome of what you like to call disinformation. In the US— and NATO—funded reports that are the basis for the Uyghur resolution, there’s not one named person interviewed who says that there is forced labour in Xinjiang, not to mention the completely fraudulent report by the American National Endowment for Democracy—funded Chinese Human Rights Defenders, which claimed there was a million Uyghurs in detention. It’s just a weapon against China – the same with Iran. This is the fourth human rights—centred attack on Iran in just over a year. I’ll take these things seriously when we stop doing them selectively. Where are the four resolutions addressing the European and US—supported genocide in Yemen? America is separating children from their mothers, and keeping them in cages by the thousands and has over two million mostly coloured people in prison carrying out forced labour. France is passing anti—Muslim legislation and still behaving like a colonialist in the Sahel, while Israel shoots children in Palestine. But that’s all okay. When we stop weaponising human rights in this place, we might have a bit more credibility.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, Iran claims to be an Islamic republic. Yet, as this resolution makes clear, it is also one of the world’s most repressive regimes. I therefore have a question for the mullahs in Tehran.  If you represent a God that is good, powerful and merciful, then why do you need to repress, torture and murder your people to this extent? No. Your regime is blasphemous and an abomination to every decent Muslim, every person of faith and every person of conscience. You have brought your country to such desperate straits that you are now signing agreements with China to give away your energy sector and your critical infrastructure. They will not complain about your human rights abuses, but I’m not sure Allah will be pleased that you are becoming vessels to a godless Communist regime. However, if you want better relations and the easing of sanctions with us, stop this repression now! What you’re doing to your own people is inhumane.  And one last thing. I have a request to the diplomats from our nation states and from our European External Action Service. Next time you meet with Mr Zarif, who is a smiling Ribbentrop, just remember what kind of nasty regime he represents.

name: Evin INCIR
text: – Madam President, dear friends, human rights is the radical notion that all people are born equal and that we will never compromise on neither civil rights nor social rights. It is radical because we still see oppression in way too many countries. Yes, it is a paradox because, on the one hand, humanity is able to fly to the moon and back, but, at the same time, some people do not know how to respect all peoples, freedom and dignity. One of the current worst oppressing regime is the Iranian one, but we will never be silent. Ahmadreza Djalali and Nasrin Sotoudeh, and other human rights defenders’ struggle for human rights, democracy and the rule of law, will continue being at the centre of everything we do.  To the Iranian regime, my message is very clear: we will continue to be vocal. We will continue to demand the release of all prisoners of conscience, the abolishment of the death penalty, and the time for an end to impunity will also come in your case. If history has taught us something, it is that dictators and oppressive regimes always fall – but the people always prevail.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, it is already the third resolution of this Parliament addressing the gross human rights violations in Iran. There is no change or improvement in the situation. The mullahs’ regime continues the fight against its own society and remains the main threat to the Iranian people. Today we mourn Iranian journalist Ruhollah Zam, who was executed on Saturday. We worry that the Iranian-Swedish academic Ahmadreza Djalali might be the next, and express concerns over the deteriorating health of imprisoned Sakharov Prize laureate Nasrin Sotoudeh. We deplore the oppressive actions of the Iranian regime, which is nothing more but weak in its incapacity to face critical political competition and embrace differences in opinion of people. We have to insist on a full and impartial UN—led investigation of the 1988 massacre of thousands of political prisoners in Iran and secure accountability by prosecuting perpetrators.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am now dedicated my words to Mrs Nasrin Sotoudeh.  The ayatollahs at the head of the Islamic Republic of Iran discredit, even offend Islam. In their documents they write in the name of God, the most compassionate and the most merciful, but their malignant and destabilizing daily action is based only on oppression. They are men full of wrath, contemptuous of human dignity and the wealth that comes from diversity. As the European Union, we have to admit that it was out of sight and even a little naïve to think of limiting the P5+1 agreement to the nuclear issue alone, we should also have included freedom of thought and human rights. We think that governing a modern state with religion is a mental insane one. Not integrating human dignity into its government action is a murderer and we must fight the murderers and be on the side of the people of Israel.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: – Madam President, fundamental rights such as freedom of expression and assembly must always be respected. I strongly condemn the steadily deteriorating human rights situation in Iran, including for persons belonging to ethnic and religious minorities suffering from systematic political and social discrimination. We deplore Iran’s abuse of the criminal justice system to repress peaceful activities that promote and defend human rights. I call on the Iranian authorities to live up to their international obligations. In this context I welcome the adoption of the Magnitsky Act by the Council as an important EU instrument to sanction violators of human rights. While maintaining the joint comprehensive plan of action and EU-Iran high-level political dialogue, the EU, and especially the High Representative, should continue raising human rights concerns with the Iranian authorities in bilateral and multilateral fora.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, yesterday we gave the Sakharov Prize to a woman, and to all those women who are opposing an authoritarian regime. I grew up in a communist regime and remember when I had the right to vote for the first time. Now I’m standing here in the Parliament, as a woman, as a Member of Parliament, looking at you, as a Commissioner, a woman, and the President, who is a woman, and all these women who are fighting for the freedom of somebody when we still don’t know whether she is alive or dead or if she’s ill. She was the winner of our Sakharov Prize in 2012 and we are still negotiating and we are still talking to the regime that is holding this woman, scared, alone, forgotten by all of us. I feel ashamed. I feel ashamed as a woman and I feel ashamed as somebody who is looking at all of you, divided by ideology: Who are we going to judge and condemn? Which regime, and who, are we going to talk to? There is no negotiation with the people who are holding women in prison. As women, they have the courage to defend and to defend against all those who are oppressing people, who are oppressing minorities and who are oppressing all those who have different beliefs to their beliefs.  Please let us fight for this woman. Let us fight for this man who is was waiting for his death sentence. Let’s use our instruments. Maybe we don’t have heavy weapons, but we have a new act that puts sanctions on all these regimes. Let’s use them in a proper way without discrimination and without division. Let’s use them and let’s make everybody not lose hope.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her How many more people have to lose their lives? That was my first thought when I heard about the execution of Ruhollah Zam. My second? The mullahs' regime seems to have no other answer than brutal violence to increasing criticism and pressure from the population. That is why it was an important sign for the Member States concerned and of Josep Borrell to cancel their participation in the EU-Iran Business Forum on Monday. But I miss clear words – especially deeds. For example, the EEAS did not mention in any syllable that the execution was a political prisoner whose execution tramples on freedom of expression, freedom of the press, our European values and human rights. Mr Borrell, representatives of the Member States, we must prevent further political prisoners from being executed. In the next exchange with the regime, put your finger in the wound, talk about what is against human rights. Talk directly to the democratic opposition. Let us directly support role models such as Nasrin Sotudeh or the fourteen women who called for Khamenei's resignation in their opposition to the regime. For a peaceful future and a balance of power in the Middle East, we need a democratic Iran that defends human rights and does not trample them underfoot. I therefore hope that next year we will have good reason to propose and award the prize to the Iranian opposition to the Sakharov Prize.

name: Gianna GANCIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission, Nasrin Sotoudeh and Ahmad Reza Jalali: their names are a warning to us Europeans. Their lives are hanging by a thread and every day can be the last, as can thousands of political opponents and members of the public held in Iranian prisons. We must also give a voice to those who no longer have the voice: 30 000 political prisoners massacred in 1988, 1 500 demonstrators murdered in November 2019. All this cannot leave us indifferent: the Ayatollah regime continues to refuse to implement the sixty-seven UN resolutions on human rights in the country. That is not acceptable. Tehran continues to deny the evidence, to disregard its commitments, to violate international treaties, not just on human rights. The European Union must go further than the sanctions regime and use all diplomatic means to set up an international commission of inquiry into the 1988 massacre and to put an end to this incredible terrorism.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, it is a very good habit that we monitor what is happening to the people to whom the European Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize. This is also positive in the context of this year's laureate, the Belarusian opposition, which will still need this support, although I hope that as soon as possible.  And returning to Iran, indeed, the regime is going further and further, so all the efforts of the European institutions in the fight against this regime, in the fight for freedom of expression, must be supported. We have received terrible news of the execution of the next death penalty for respecting fundamental values and principles in Iran. I therefore call on the High Representative of the Union to step up all action, to press the Iranian regime and to defend these key principles and fundamental values. Besides, of course, we must do everything to ensure that Nasrin Sotoudeh leaves prison as soon as possible. This is a great task for the EU institutions.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The citizen Ahmadreza Djalali is a doctor and researcher in disaster medicine. He has been imprisoned in Iran since 2016. In 2017, he was sentenced to death. On 24 November this year he called his wife, here in Sweden. He let her know that this was probably their very last conversation. Ahmadreza Djalali is one of the victims of the brutal increase in political repression in Iran. With this resolution, we would like to express our disgust at the abuses of the Iranian regime against individuals, against women, against men. Now the persecution of journalists and researchers and those who have only used their freedom of expression must come to an end. The innocent prisoners must be released. The death penalty must be abolished. Now Ahmadreza Djalali must be allowed to return home to Sweden, to his family, to his wife, to his children, where he belongs.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Nasrin Sotoudeh has been recently returned to prison and is facing clear health difficulties. Once again, we have asked that she be released and reunited with her family.  The European Union is closely following human rights developments in Iran, and we are acutely aware of the deterioration that has occurred over the past year. Iran’s execution of dissident Ruhollah Zam last Saturday is of course deeply worrying. As noted in the statement issued by the spokesperson for the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the European Union condemns this act in the strongest terms and recalls once again its irrevocable opposition to the use of capital punishment under any circumstances. Iran continues to execute more than 200 individuals every year. We believe that it is imperative for the Iranian authorities to uphold the due process rights of accused individuals and to cease the practice of using televised confessions to establish and promote their guilt.  All individuals found to have been involved in serious human rights violations, including during the response to the November 2019 protests in Iran, should be held accountable. While we recognise that Iran continues to host hundreds of thousands of refugees, the human rights situation in Iran remains deeply concerning. The authorities’ repression of peaceful protest and other gatherings continues unabated. Such repression, the restriction of fundamental freedoms, and discrimination against religious and ethnic minorities are features of life for too many Iranian citizens. Iran also continues to hold a number of EU—Iranian dual nationals on doubtful grounds, following trials where the due process rights of the accused were not respected in full.  This includes Ahmadreza Djalali – whose situation many Members of this House are following – who remains at risk of imminent execution and whose life we ask be spared.  We regularly engage with the authorities to urge improvements in the human rights situation in Iran as part of our comprehensive policy towards Iran. This includes asking that the repression of human rights lawyers and defenders, peaceful protesters, ethnic and religious minorities cease, and that individuals detained as a result of their advocacy for universally recognised human rights be freed.  Iran should uphold its domestic and international commitments on human rights, including the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights, to which it is party. We have been vocal in this demand, including at international forums such as the United Nations Human Rights Council and through public statements whenever justified.  As the EU, we will continue to call for the release of all arbitrarily detained EU-Iranian dual nationals and Iranian human rights defenders. We also call on Iran to ensure that no individual is detained arbitrarily, that those who are detained are not subject to any form of mistreatment. All detained individuals should also have timely access to a lawyer of their own and to adequate medical care. This is particularly relevant to the cases of the eight environmentalists who have been detained since January 2018. One of these individuals, Morad Tahbaz, continues to experience severe health problems.  We are encouraged by the attention paid to these issues by individual Members of the European Parliament, and we will continue with our efforts to work together with you in order to promote access to fundamental human rights in Iran and across the world.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: in writing. The imprisonment of lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh is the clearest demonstration of the dictatorial and anti-freedom nature of the Islamic Republic of Iran. We wonder how long Europe will remain silent, in the face of iran's repeated violations of human rights. The Commission has done nothing for the immediate release of Nasrin Sotoudeh and all political prisoners in Iranian prisons. We are firmly on the side of the activists who work to defend rights and who cry out to the world, the urgent need for freedom for women and for all the oppressed. Europe too often, out of good will and fear, has not openly condemned the treatment of women in many Islamic countries. This silence is no longer acceptable!
